Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What do people use to absorb extra ink from a fountain pen? Choices:  A: shirt pocket B: calligrapher's hand C: inkwell D: desk drawer E: blotter<n><n>### Response:		<n>- [ ] Calligrapher's Hand -> If we take A<n>- [ ] Inkwell -> If we take C<n>- [ ] Shirt Pocket -> If we take B<n>- [ ] Desk Drawer -> If we take D<n>- [ ] Blotter -> If we take E<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response that appropriately answers or directs the question. Write a response that answers or directs according to each scenario given.<n><n>### Scenario:<n>The grocery store is having a big sale.  If you buy 7 items and spend less than $100, you get a coupon for $40.  Additionally, you get $5 worth of grocery cards for every person you invite.  Write a program that tells a person if they will profit from this sale.  If there is not enough information, print, "No info.". If there are no grocery cards, write "No grocery cards." to let the customer know.<n><n>### Answer:<n>- [ ] If they spend less than $110, or less than $116, they profit.<n>- [ ] If there are grocery cards and they buy 8 items, they profit.<n><n>- [ ] If their name is Jack, they should buy 15 items and spend less than 1750 dollars.  If a name is not Jack, then they should buy 8 items and spend less than<n><n>### Instructor's Answer:<n>- [X] If they spend less than 100 bucks, they profit.<n>If there is not enough information they should answer, "No info."<n>- [X] if there's no grocery card then they should answer "No Grocery Cards."<n>- [X ] If name is Jack, they'd need to spend less than $1760 with 15 items in total.<n>Name is not Jack, they only need 8 items and less than $11 and no grocery card.<n><n>### Output<n><n>Input: What do people use to absord extra ink from a pen? Choices: A: <n>Shoe box -> If you take A<n><n>Input: How can you tell if a pterodactyl is in an elevator? Choices: A

Something can be both good and bad at the same time."<n>```<n><n>### Instance:<n>One week after the exam, I received my exam grade back on the following line: "You scored 85% on the exam." This was exemplifying extreme because I passed 85 percent in the class with my high score.<n><n>### Output:<n>When something is the best of the worst, it is exemplify extreme.<n>This can be something that'sim excellent or dreadful.Something can be both good and  bad at the same time.<n><n>### Questionnaire:<n>One week after  the exam, I  received my  exam grade  back  on  the following line:  "You scored 87% on  the exam." When the right answer is chosen, the program will say "That's correct!" and end. Otherwise, it will continue to ask the question and respond "Try again."<n><n>When the program ends, print this message: Thank you for playing!<n><n>### Expectations for the Program<n>The program should require the user to answer the question, and in one case should not quit on the user if they guess wrong.<n><n>### Submission:<n>To submit your code, zip up src.zip and upload the archive to Gradescope.<n><n>### Running Your Code<n>This project requires that you place a program in a subdirectory called src and that you name your program main.c.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Who is likely yo have a caring heart? Choices:  A: person B: species C: artichoke D: all mammals E: live animal<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### If a species is caring<n>You can identify which species are caring by looking at their appearance and the types of things they do. For example, dogs are known to be caring. They are loyal and loving which is one of the important things a caring animal needs to have. All mammals also display caring behaviors which makes it more likely for a caring heart to be found in this group. If an animal in the mammal category is identified as a caring heart, it is most likely a dog.<n><n>#### If an animal is caring<n>All animals are capable of displaying caring behaviors. However, an animal is likely to have a caring heart if it does one of the following:<n>- is part of the group of animals that have been identified as caring<n>- uses its caring heart behavior to help the animal that it cares about<n>- shows an ability to understand what is happening in a complex situation<n><n>#### If a person is caring<n>Being caring about a person usually means that you treat them with fairness and respect. It also means that you have a concern for their well-being and a desire to create a positive, trusting relationship with them. Caring typically requires that a person be more mature, kinder, and calmer than other people.<n><n>### Input A: I am 5 feet tall. Input B: Your height is 4 inches shorter than mine. What is my height in centimeters?<n><n>### Response A:<n>![](https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/517890940694642304/693761415590593952/unknown.png)<n>### Response B:<n>![](https//media.discordappnet/attachments/698283622954544064/914456065902219913/unknown.png)    <n><n>### Input C: Answer: You need 20% of it.<n><n>### Response C:<n>To get a fraction as a percentage, just remove the decimal point.  <n>So, 20% means getting a number like this: 50 or 1.5 or 10

Choices:  A: shake hands B: control events C: talk to each other D: think creatively E: dress themselves<n><n>### Response:		<n>Letter: E is correct. We would like to invite you to try thinking creatively.<n><n>### Response 2:<n><n>We have been thinking creatively all this time.<n><n>### Feedback:<n>**Correct:** In the example, the creativity was expressed as writing a letter, therefore making the second response false.<n><n>**Wrong**: Both the response examples will be given feedback since both response examples are incorrect.**Letter:** In the example above, all the people in this class was controlled.<n><n>### Suggested Changes:<n>Instruction: The question is a bit tricky... we should be more specific.  <n>Demonstration: You could have skipped the line that said 'In the example, all of the people...'.  It's kinda redundant.  Maybe an exercise to work on later?  <n>Response: The last part is very vague'response that would be expected'.  If people have to say something or not?<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:If your watching television and accomplish nothing what have you done? Choices:  A: getting fat B: get fat C: typing words D: falling asleep E: wasted time<n><n>### Response:		<n>This program will take the input, look at it, and generate the appropriate output without the use of any external methods. To do this, create a function `answerMe`, which takes a string as input, and returns a string with the output. To do this, we'll be using a while loop to read in input and print out the answer until the correct response is received. Your class should have the method declaration:<n><n>`def answerMe(input):`<n><n>Then, inside of the method declaration, create a string variable `answer`, and declare the while loop:<n><n>`while True:`<n><n>Next, set the input string to be the input, and then put the answer statement inside the while loop. The answer string will have a for loop to iterate through all possible options.<n><n>```python<n>ans = ''<n>answer = ''<n><n>while True:`<n>   answer = input(input).lower()<n><n>   for option in answerMe:<n>      if answer == option:<n>         print(answerMe + '\n');<n>         break;<n>   else:<n>      print('You didn\'t give a valid answer');<n><n>```<n>Finally, create a function `Answer`, to wrap your code so that you don't get a syntax error.<n><n>`def Answer():`<n><n>Your class must produce the following output:<n><n>```python<n>>>> A:<n>>>> B:<n>>>> C:<n>>>> D:<n>>>> E:<n>>>> F:<n>```<n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:John ran out of pencils.  Where did  he go to get more? Choices:  A: desk drawer B: cup C: pencil case D: shelf E: office depot<n><n>### Response:		Please enter choices.<n><n>### Input and output:<n>John goes to the desk drawer for more pencils.  John goes to the office depot for more pencils<n><n>This is the task instruction and the task data provided. You are to write a program to respond to this request.  Once you have written a program for this task that does so, run your program and paste the output here.<n><n>This is an example of what your response should look like<n><n>Input:John ran out of pens.  Where did  you go to get more?  Choices:  A : desk drawer B : cup.  C : pencil case D : shelf  E : office depot<n>Response: Please enter input.<n>Response: Please enter choices.  <<n>Response: Please enter selection. <<n>Response: Please Enter Input(1 - desk).<n>Response: Please Enter Selection (a - desk), (b - cup), (c - pen) (d - shelf), (e - office depot).<n>Response: Please Enter Choice. <<n>Choice: <n>Choice: 1<n>Choice: 56<n>response: Please enter selections.<n><n>The 56 indicates the answer. This was achieved by calling the `input` function and then using `choice` function to read in a selection.<n><n>Now your task is to write a program that reads in a choice.  The choice is either `a` 'for the first selection, `b`  for the second selection, `c` for the third selection, `d` for the fourth session, `e` for the fifth session and `enter` key for the end session.<n><n>The value returned to you depends on how the choice function is used.  The choice function will return the value that was entered in the choice. The choice function does two things, it provides a prompt and then accepts a value.<n><n>The first thing to understand about the choice function is that it requires a choice name.  The choice name is used to identify the variable that holds the value entered.  The name should be unique and not already used for any other variable in the program.<n><n>### Example of how to Use the Choice Function<n><n>``` cpp<n>    int userChoice;     //this variable holds the choice made<n>    string userSelection;<n>    string input;<n>```<n>### Example

A word should consist of a string of characters from 0 to 9, the letter S, and a space in between. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The man wanted to take a bus, but all the chars were full of people doing what? Choices:  A: sitting down B: refusing C: saving money D: sit down E: go outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is option E, the man wanted to take a car, but all the seats on the bus were full<n><n>## Solution<n>---<n>* In the first line of the input, the first line contains an assignment.<n><n>* In the second line, the next two lines describe the input, including two values.<n><n>* The value to the left is the price per unit and the value to the right is the quantity of the same product.<n><n>* In each line of the third line, the third line describes every choice including the number of times a choice occurs. It has five choices total.<n>> Option A: "sitting down" The answer is the same as B<n><n>>  Option B: "refusing" The corresponding answer is C<n><n>> Option C: "saving money" The answer is option D<n><n>> Option D: "sit down" The answer is option E<n><n>> Option E: "go outdoors" The answer is option F<n><n>* The answer for the fourth line is the total price of what the man buys.<n><n>### Acknowledgements<n><n>* [Problem](https://leetcode.com/explore/interview/card/top-coding-interview-questions-easy/62/array/1948/)

Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:If I screw a chain ring onto something, what am I fixing? Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the following expression<n>### Solution:<n><n><n>### Input::Most of my friends are really into rock music.<n>What do you like? The most popular music on my side of town right now is: Choices:  A B: reggae music B: electronic music C: R&B D: heavy metal  E: country music<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Solution: A<n><n>### Input : The cost of an outdoor party is $30 per person.  Our event is for 40 guests.  How much does the outing cost?<n><n>### Demowstration:<n><n><n><n>### Democracy 2020.  Candidates are allowed to submit debate questions. Choices:  A: bookstore B: library C: doctor D: home E: table<n><n>### Response:		<n>I'm wondering about the price of magazines. It's a common misconception that magazines are cheaper than books, but actually magazines can be quite expensive. Most people keep magazines at their home. The price, while not much, is reasonable. The magazines they keep are also not cheap ones; they are mostly expensive and sophisticated. They are expensive because they contain the best quality content and stories, as well as the most up-to-date research and news on the topic.

In this game, player moves a small spaceship around a giant rotating disk.  There are 3 asteroids, all at a random location on the disk.  If a single asteroid comes into contact with the ship, the game is lost.  The game ends when the player completes 50 levels before the time runs out. There are also smaller rocks that the player can avoid by moving away from their previous location. Avoiding the rocks also increases the score at a rate of 200.00.<n><n>### Input 1: What is the number of 2nd rocks?<n><n>### Choice 1: None, there is only one.<n><n>### Choices:<n><n><n>### Choose none because only 1 can be chosen at a time<n><n>### Choiced 1: There isn't just 1 asteroid, but 3<n><n>### Why<n>Because "levels" are 50<n><n>### Why 2<n>Because it's not the first asteroid<n><n>### Instance:What are the requirements for a good job application? Choices: 1: Must be in alphabetical order 2: Must list all information required. 3: Must provide all the details requested. 4: Must be one page or less.<n>### Choice:3<n><n><n>### Input2:When the player gets hit by one asteroid, the game continues.  After a hit, the game keeps looping around the disk until it's over. How many times does the player need to continue after getting hit?<n><n>### Answer: 7<n><n>### Why?<n>There are 3 asteroins and if each one hits you you lose the game<n><n>### What was the solution?<n>Each time an asteroid hits the game continues 7 times<n><n><n>### What is the solution?<n>There are

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:James lived in the top of a tall tower.  He could see clouds when he looked out his window.  Where might he live? Choices:  A: in books B: radio station C: city D: tower E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write your code here..!<n><n>### Response.<n>    if((isInt(val1) && isInt(val2)){<n>    if(isInt(val1)>isInt(val2)){cost=val1;}<n>    else{cost=val2;}<n>}<n>    else{<n>    alert("Parsing failed.");<n>    }<n><n>### Output:<n>[0, -55, 4, 4, "A", "A"]<n><n>

Input: The train driver is going to need to turn right.  He is going to need to slow down.  There are 78 other people on the train.  He needs to slow down to go faster.<n><n>2. The correct answer is 85. ( 78 multiplied by 78). The driver needs to stop as fast as he can so he can slow down. He needs to turn in a certain amount of time. He needs to get the people to their seats.<n><n>3.Input: If a student gets 10 points on a test.  They should do better on the next exam.  But each time they get a 0.5 point on the next exam. They should be able to get a certain amount of points to get an A.  If one person needs to get 60 points to get an A then that means that it would be easy to do better and get a certain amount of correct answers on the next quiz.  If that is the case then they can raise their score to a 85 and they should be able to get an A.<n><n>4.Input: The answer is that if you go fast you can go slow and if you go slow you can go fast if you can turn right.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n><n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where do you keep a teakettle? Choices:  A: cupboard B: countertop C: water D: hardware department E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you have a cupboard, place a teakettle there. If you don’t have a cupboard, you can put a teakettle on the countertop or water. If you don’ t have either a cupboard or a countertop, a teakettle might be best kept in the hardware department or England.<n><n>### Input:(a) 2 +5(b) 1 -5(c) 2 –5<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: How much does 1/5 -1/5 cost? Input: How much does 2/5 -2/5 cost?<n><n>Answer: 19.5 Answer: 49.5<n><n>Input: How much could 5/10 –$4 cost?<n><n>Answer:$35.5<n><n>### Input:# (a) 4 (b) $ (c)2<n><n>### Solution: 17 (6)#2 31 (7) (a)#3 $ (5)#2 39 (13).<n><n>2 is the greatest value greater than #1. Because if I want to have two digits after point, and one digit before point, I will need to use three digits. So, the third digit is $3 (9) and we end up at 39 (9).<n><n>### Input:{3.7,2.5,1.2}<n><n>### Inputs: How do you spell 'casserole'? Is ‘l’ silent?  Which animal is the fastest?<n>Answers: Casserole<n><n>Answer: cat and fastest<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Jan went to the auditorium and listened to the speech. Where might he be? Choices:  A: crowd B: high school C: city D: somewhere E: theater<n><n>### Response:		<n>The speech took place at an auditorium, so Jan must be somewhere that contains an auditorium. Aside from the crowded location, we cannot draw conclusions about a location. It is not possible to decipher from this information where Jan went and what he planned to do.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Jan went to the audtorium to listen to a speech.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>Jan listened to the speech inside the auditorium.<n><n>### Infer:<n><n>- - - - - - -<n>You may want to draw a diagram of a house and fill out this table.<n><n>| Top Floor| Bottom Floor| Outside of the House|<n>|---|---|---|<n>| Truck | Garage |<n><n>| Bedroom| Bathroom| Living Room|<n>|---|--|---|<n>| 1, 2, 3| 1, 4, 5|<n><n>- - -. - - - - - <n>You may want to describe what you see if you take out your phone and look at "this" picture.<n><n>### Response<n><n>In the picture there appears to be the same man on the left wearing a hat, and on the right he is wearing a cap. The man is also wearing a purple shirt, and the women appears to be wearing white. They are both sitting in chairs in the same building. I don't think that there is any relation between the two people, there could be, but the only information that we have to draw such a conclusion is the building. I do not know where anyone else in the picture could be. I do not know whether it is day or night, or anything else about the picture.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Johnny was looking for blowfish in places that weren't near America.  Where would he look? Choices:  A: fish market B: hawaiian waters C: gulf of mexico D: tropical sea E: south pacific ocean<n><n>### Response:		 C = 100<n>Answer location is a function of latitude and longitude.  Choices must be valid coordinates.  Gulf of Mexico is located in Florida.  Hawaii is not located in Florida so B is incorrect.  Tropical water is located in Central and South America and not Hawaii so E is incorrect.  Johnny does not need to travel to Florida, Hawaii, Central America and South America.  So the answer is C = 10.<n><n><n><n><n><n>

How many colors do they not have?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>>Answer: 4  <n>>Yellow is in the third list ("not", "dog"), but not in the second list. You can tell by the position of Yellow that it is also in the first list.   Blue is in the fourth list ("dog", "not"), but not in the first list. You can tell that blue is not in the second list either.   Red is in the second list ("dog", "dog"), and also in the third list ("dog", "yet").   Orange is in the first list ("yet", "dog"), and in the fourth list ("not", "red").   Green is not in any list.<n><n>### Input<n>>What is the 3rd longest river in Europe<n><n>### Demosration<n>>Answer: O, A, S, N  <n>>(Tributaries aren't included)<n>####Rivers by length (km)<n>1. If you got it right, it will cost.05 cents. <n><n>### Input/Inputs:<n>`.05(P(got wrong) =.5)`<n><n>### Outputs/response:<n>`.5(.05) =.025`<n><n>### Assuption:<n>You could simply have a random function that flips a coin as to whether or not the user would rather spray themselves with perfume. <n>

Choices:  A: new hampshire B: dairy farm C: farm field D: texas E: county fair<n><n>### Response:		<n>```Python<n># First we create an empty empty string for each possible value. <n># We can do a for loop to create an empty string, one at a time, and we will see that we can use for loops for other things too. <n># Empty strings for our possibilities, and empty string variables called 'answer' which will store which of the answers is true..<n># Loop through those strings in search for a match<n><n># Then we check if it is present<n><n>if any(answer==x for x in answers): <n>    print('you chose: ',answer)<n>else: <n>    print('sorry, the answer was not selected: ',x)<n>```<n><n>### Explain your code<n>### This is a very hard test<n>

Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where would one find a captive monkey? If you went to the toy store, the monkey is not captive as you can take it home. Thus, the place where one would find a captive mony is in the zoo.  <n><n><n>

Choices:  A: heartburn B: have fun C: enjoy D: gas E: food poisoning<n><n>### Response:		 E<n><n>### Answer explanation:<n><n>In this problem, you will have 20 input questions.<n>Your program should have 20 output questions. Each input question describes a food item available at a local fast food restaurant.  After inputting these items, you should then write 20 output questions for each item. <n><n>For example, let's take the first question in this program:<n>```<n>A: burrito B: chicken C: cheese D: enchilada E: pizza<n>```<n><n>The program should contain an answer that either selects:<n>```<n>B, C, D, or E<n>```<n><n>### Input/Output<n><n>This function will return a list of choices based upon the item input in the question.  There will be one or two choices per item, depending on how many ways to make the food item.<n><n>You will need to have three separate functions.<n><n>Firstly make a function to generate a list of possible answers with a prompt and list of items.  Secondly, you will generate a list of ways to make each specific item listed in the answer. Lastly you will create a list of answers generated in the second function by printing each specific item listed in answer.<n><n>Let's say you're asked the question:<n><n>```Input: Burritos are rolled up tortillas filled with meat, cheese, vegetables, and beans. Rice is an optional additive.  What kind of food can you make with burritos? Choices: <n>     A: burrito wrap B: burrito bowl C: burrito bowl lunchmeat D: enchiladas<n>```<n><n>Once you press 'Enter' on the keyboard, you will get some possible answers.<n>You will have to print a message at the top of the page similar to what is shown in the "Input: Demonstration:" section above.  <n>A user presses 'Enter' twice, once for each item and you will see the choices for each answer.<n><n>```<n>B: burrito wrap<n><n>B: burrito bowl<n><n>B: burritow bowl lunchmeats<n>```

You can assume the presence of devices like switches, routers, computers, mobile devices, Wi-Fi APs, Internet Services, Firewalls, and various software tools like content/url filtering software.  You can choose to use whatever you wish. <n><n>* No single device can do it all, but for this section, they can be treated as though they can.<n><n>* You can and should assume unlimited resources.<n><n>* You may chose to have a single endpoint that acts like a sponge that holds data that is stored (and accessed as needed) on an endpoint.<n><n><n>* You MAY NOT assume any single device type or software (for example, don't assume a network firewall will do this, don't assume that only URL software will do this, don’t assume that a network switch will do this with the traffic passing over it).<n><n>* You CAN make suggestions on whether to use a software solution or a hardware solution.<n><n>* You MAKE A RECOMMENDATION as to what the solution should be and WHY the recommendation you’

B: in the building.<n><n>### Input_Description:<n>How do you feel after work?<n><n>### Response_Description:<n>While I work, I am usually too busy to think of how I am feeling.  I don't usually remember until I go back to my room and watch TV.  By the time I go home, I tend to be so exhausted that I don't remember how I was feeling before work.  Somehow during the day, I feel a sense of accomplishment and happiness from finishing the day with success.<n><n>### Response Type: Informative<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What kind of people will someone who is in charge of project look for? Choices:  A: greedy B: worry C: have knowledge D: take charge E: boss<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```java<n><n>"Greedy."<n>```<n><n>[https://www.dropbox.com/s/wmd15q25s876117/test.png?dl=0](https://www.dropBox.com/s/jL4bZY51WjWjDGw/answer.jpg?dl=0)<n><n>### Discussion: If you're not sure which answer is correct, describe the problem instead:<n><n>This question needs more details to determine the correct answer.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```java <n>public class Solution {<n>    public int minimum(int[][] intervals) {<n>        int[] num = new int[6];<n>        for(int i = 0; i < 6; i++){<n>			num[i] = intervals[i][1] - intervals[i][0];<n>		}<n>        int ans = Integer.MAX_VALUE;<n>        for (int i = 0, k = 0; i< 6; i++){ // 6 == num.length<n>            if (num[i] < 0)<n>                num[i] = 0;<n>            if (k%2 ==1 && num[i]<0){<n><n>            	num[i]++;<n>            	k++;<n>        }<n>        	else if(k%2 ==0 && num[i]>0){<n>            	num[k]++;<n>            	ans = Math.min(ans, num[i]);<n>            	k++; //k is the current position to be updated to the next num<n>            }<n>      }<n>      ans = Math.min(2*ans, Math.min(k-1, ans));<n>      ans=Math.min(ans, Math.min((k-i-1)/2,ans));<n>      ans=ans/k+ans/i+ans;<n>      if(ans*k > 6){<n>        return 6;<n>      }<n>      return ans;<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n>  <n>### Resources / Comments:<n>*[Java Code](https://github.com/johnnysunny/interview-codes/tree/master/codes/2020-11-01-S3)*<n>

What the person asks ----->What you answer<n><n>### Choice A: loss of consciousn (Sorry, this is loss of consciousness, not snoring)<n><n>(Correct)<n><n>### Choices B: Relaxation (Sorry, this sounds more right, this is relaxation. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What place would a person go to look at zebras? Choices:  A: zoo B: museum C: hospital D: desk E: opera<n><n>### Response:		<n>If person were to look at zebra they would be most likely in a zoo but that is not always the case. <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a program that, given an amount of money, adds enough 1 and 5 currency coins until the total money is greater than or equal to the amount passed to the program.<n>If you want to make the coins, just make one 2 times of the difference of the amount you want to make and add to the original input.<n>e.g.: If you are given amount 50, make this coins:<n>0 cents<n>50 cents<n><n>Input: 20 -> should come out with 30, because you will need 1 5 (1 = 0, 5 = 5)<n><n><n>### What to do:<n><n>Given a number as a parameter, find out how many coins you would need to make <n><n>### What you get:<n>Input: 25 -> Output: 35 (in the form of 25, [5], 35) <n><n>### Write your program:<n><n>1. Take user input<n><n>2. Take amount of money<n><n>3. Use a loop<n><n>### Sample Solution<n><n>```python<n>def roll(amount):<n>    '''Given a number as the amount parameter, find how many coins are needed.'''<n>    counter = 0<n>    if amount%5 == 0:<n>        # amount is even<n>        return counter<n>    elif amount%5 == 1:<n>        return counter + 2<n>    else:<n>        return counter+(amount-1)<n><n><n>```<n><n>### Test it<n><n>```python<n>amount = 50<n>print(roll(amount))<n>```<n><n>```<n>Output:<n>50, [5], 55<n>```<n><n>## What is a loop?<n>- A method that can be repeated and will be executed until a condition is met.<n>	- Example:<n>		- While(condition): [executable step]<n>		- Do-while: [executable step], [done]<n><n>## What is for-in loop?<n><n><n>## What is While loop?<n><n>

Choices:  A: appear suddenly B: bottom out C: go downtown D: scream E: roll over<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Your Solution:<n>* #### Answer: E<n>* #### How the code works: (You can use pseudo code or an image)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity. Given an Integer array and an integer k, return the number of triplets (subarrays of equal elements) which sum to K, assuming the integer array is in ascending order and is not sorted according to K. In other words, you will receive an integer array of N elements and need to return the number of subsets that sum to the given K.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>Input: 1 1 1 3 5 6 7 8 8<n>Output: 2 (array = [1 3 6 8] sum = 3, array = [1 4 5 7] sum = 3), 1 (array = [1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8] sum = K)<n>### Explanation:<n>Since the input array contains distinct elements, when the elements are being arranged into triplets for each index i, if the sum of i, i + 1, and i + 2 is K, then it is counted as a triplet. <n><n>Input: 0<n>Output: 0<n><n>### Instuction:<n>Write a program that prints number of triplets that sum to target k for

Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What is the purpose of the cabin in an airplane? One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The print was extremely small, as he was reading letter after letter he began to suffer eye what? Choices:  A: strain B: though C: happiness D: realization E: understanding<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>Input:The print was extremely low, as he was reading sentence after sentence, he began to suffer eye strain.<n><n>Input:The printer was so loud his wife was on the brink of a nervous breakdown.  Choices: B: though C: of A: realization D: understanding E: happiness<n><n>### Response B<n><n>Input:The pizza was so hot and spicy she had to spit out half of her plate.  Choices: A: a B: spat C: sheer D: spindle E: spit<n><n>### Response A<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:If I have a reception with many people attending, where should I be sure to hold it? Choices:  A: grand casino B: large room C: restaurant D: country club E: lobby<n><n>### Response:		<n>```javascript<n>let choices = ["A", "B", "C", "D", "E"]<n>let inputLet = input.trim();<n>let correctGuess;<n>let guess;<n>if (inputLet == "E" ){<n>    guess = "Large room";<n>}<n>if(inputLet == "C" ){<n>    guess= "Country club"<n>}<n>if (inputLet== "D" ){<n>    guess="Lobby"<n>}<n>if(choices.findIndex(x=> x=="Lobby") ) ){<n>    correctGuess= "Large room";  <n>}<n>```<n><n>### Input : You have a number of friends with various food allergies and are trying to throw a party. Choices:  A) Milk allergy, peanut allergy, egg allergy B) Dairy allergy, gluten allergy, egg allerger C) Gluten allergy, nut allergy, egg allergen, fish allergy, soy allergy D) Milk allergy and gluten allergy are the only major risks<n>E) Milk allergy, nut allergy, wheat allergy F) None of these<n><n>### Response<n>```javascript<n>let input = "Dairy allergy, nut allerry and gluten allergy";<n>let output = "Choices: A, E";<n>if(/m, s, g/g.test(input)){<n>    output="A";<n>}<n>if(/a//|d/g.test(output)){<n>    output="E";<n>}<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:As a human in a large northeastern city, where can you see animals? Choices:  A: zoo B: workplace C: sky D: new york city E: many places<n><n>### Response:		The list of answers is in alphabetical order.<n><n>### Input<n>The question consists of one line containing five word with space character in between. For example, there answer is ( A, B, C, D, and E ).<n><n>### Output<n>Print the question. The first line contains a non-negative natural number, specifying the number of answers that the user types. Then in the each line, print a single character for each answer.<n><n>### Example<n>Input:  A zoo<n>Output:<n>A zoo<n>B<n>C<n>D<n>E<n><n>### Your Own Code<n>### Concept<n>1. Use if-else statements to output for the question.<n>    - If first word is `A:`, the first line has 3 words<n>    ```java<n>    string[] tempArray = question.split(" ");<n>    if (tempArray[0].equalsIgnoreCase("A:")) {<n>        System.out.println("A:")<n>        for (int i = 1; i < tempArray.length; i++) {<n>            System.out.print(tempArray[i].trim().toUpperCase() + " ");<n>        }<n>    }<n>    return true;<n>    ```<n>2. Use switch-case to print for the answer.<n>    - If the first word is `A`, use switch-case <n>    ```java<n>     String switchCh = question.split(" ")[0]; // split the first word from the string<n>     System.out.println(switchCh + ": ");  <n>    case 'A':<n>        System.out+ = "A: ";<n>        break;<n>    default:<n>        System.out += "Sorry. Wrong answer!"<n>        break;<n>     }<n>    }<n><n>### Output:<n><n>#### A zoo<n>Input:A zoo<n>Output:<n><n>#### B<n>Input:<n>B<n><n>#### C<n><n>Input:<n>C<n><n>#### D<n><n>Input:<n>D<n><n>#### E<n><n>Input:E<n>Output:many places

Out of that people, 10% of them like movies directed by Clint Eastwood.  Of those movies directed by Cliff Eastwood, 50% are westerns. The percent of westerns directed by Cliff Eastlow is 5% Which of these does not belong? (Choices: A: The number of customers who are over 30 are the exact same as the number of people that own an Apple. B: The number of people who like movies directed by Eastwood is 55.5% of people that own Apple. C: The number of people that like movies directed Eastwood is 5.5% less than the number of people who own an Apple. D: The number of movies that are westerns is 50% of the number of movies that Cliff Eastwood has directed. E: Cliff Eastwood has made 50% less movies than he did when he started his company. F: The number of moviies that are Westerns is the same of the of the number of people that were born in 1964. Choices:  A: blank B: sparse C: thin D: clear E: free flowing<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Before he had a vasectomy, Mark's semen was thick, which means it was very viscous and was hard to run. This semen was not free flowing. Mark's semen flowed freely once he had the vasectomy because his vas deferens were severed and his semen had nowhere to go. <n><n>### Input<n>What is 3+4?<n><n>### Demostration<n>1. A: 32<n>1. It is hard to say whether 3 + 4 is 7. <n><n>## Challenge<n>Use the knowledge that you have to develop a new solution not given in the challenge instructions.<n><n>### Challenge: <n>What does 2 x 4 =?  A: a) (2 x 4) B: (2 x 2 x 4)<n><n>### Challenge Demonstration<n>1. B<n><n>### Challenge Explanation: <n>We know what 2 x 4 is, and we know that two sets of parentheses can be used to perform multiplication.<n>Therefore, 2 x 4 can be written as 2 (2 x 4). If we had more than two sets of parentheses, that would be (2 x 2) (2 x 2. <n><n>## Solution : 1)<n>While trying this, keep in mind that a computer program is actually a step-by-step set of instructions that tell the computer what to do. This means, that like in a cookbook you will be given a bunch of ingredients, and a recipe for you to follow. Each line of coding should be followed up.<n><n>### First, what are the ingredients?<n>The ingredients include the actual python code. Each of this code have their own role that need to be done for the program to work.<n>1.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What might be the result of a season of successful skiing? Choices:  A: finish line B: broken bones C: broken legs D: chapped lips E: healthy body<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>if x== B or x== C or x== D:<n>    print("Choose wisely")<n>else:<n>    print(x)<n>```<n><n>#### Solution:<n><n>In the input, there are choices given in the form of variables `x`.  These variables can be strings. So, when we are checking the input, we should first convert `x` into string, and then compare them using `=` operator.<n><n>For every loop run, we will be printing the values as the input contains many options.  So, we will check in the beginning if the input is a number or string, and then check the contents of the `x` variable with each possibility of input.<n><n>`In the if statement, `B, C,D` will be converted into `b, c, d` and the `else` statement, we will check if `x` is not equal to `b, c,d` that is, it is a string.<n><n>### Input :<n>Write the Python equivalent of the following mathematical expression.<n>`= 1(7/9) + 2(5/8)`<n><n>### Solution:<n>Let`s convert the mathematical expression `7:9` to decimal and string.<n>```python<n>    print("9/7")<n><n>    print(int(7/9))<n>    print(str(7/9))```<n><n>```python<n>Input: Print 15-21 + 3-11<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: closet B: library of congress C: classroom D: in bed E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n>"My guess would be a desk." or "My guess would be that a book would be on a desk while being read." or "I would guess that a book would be kept inside a desk while being reads." or "My guess is that while a person is reading the book, it will be kept on the desk." or "When I would be reading a book, I would definitely put it in my desk." or "As I'm reading a book, I'm probably putting it in a desk."<n><n>When given a choice like this, the correct answer is A, B, or C, and the incorrect response is D or E because a desk would not contain E for many other reasons including, an item being stored at the Library of Congress, and/or being in bed.<n><n>###  Instruction:Answer the next question by responding with "A", "B", "C", or "D".<n><n>### Example: A: 40 B: 12 C: 48 D: 80<n><n>**Input:** This quiz has 18 questions. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The fat man refused to accept what was possible, he complained that he what the simplest activities? Response 2:<n><n>### Response2:<n>The fat man complained to me that you are an impossible activity.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Write appropriate response in the dialog box.<n><n>## Solution 3:<n>The fat man responded by saying an activity that is impossible.<n><n>## Solution21:<n>The fatman refuses to believe that what you're selling is a simple activity.<n><n>## Instructions:<n>The solution begins at the bottom.<n><n>## Input:<n>The fat man said that  you're an impossible thing here.<n><n>## Instruction2:<n>Write an appropriate response in the dialog.<n>Response:<n>The fat man says that you're an impossible action.<n>## Solution:Solution:<n>Write the appropriate response in dialogue.<n><n>## Soluton 2:<n>The fatman refused to believe that you're an activity.<n><n>## Soluction3:<n>The fatman replied by saying that you're in the impossible thing.<n><n>## Solutions:<n>Write an appropriate in the dialogue box<n><n><n>## Input:The fatman refused to accept what was impossible. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What is committing perjury likely to lead to? Choices:  A: shame B: arrest C: embarrassment D: go to jail E: tension<n><n>### Response:		The correct multiple answer response would be choosing answer letter D, "Go to jail";  However, the above code returns "shame" as a possible answer for this question because I have the while statement wrapped around and that means if the answer letter for this question is "shame" the question will be skipped and will proceed to the next multiple choice and the program will end after the while loop if the question is answered correctly.  If I want to return the "shame" answer, I have to either change the while statement or add a "if" statement with the answer letter's index in it.<n><n>### Input (multiple answer): What did the student do to get caught? Choices: A: cheated on a test B: copied the answers C: stole another student’s homework D: did not show up for a test<n><n>### Instructions:The multiple choice question to the right have been answered. Answer one of them using only one letter in your response. That single letter will be the answer the student is accused of.<n><n>### Response (multiple answer): The correct single answer is: "C."<n>

Choices:  A: sorrow B: paying bills C: happiness D: frustration E: spending money<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input<n>```cpp<n>constexpr int size = 10; <n>constexpr int sum = 0;<n>int array[] = { 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 }; <n>const auto res = transform(array, array + size, sum += transform(array, array, sum += array[x+1]));<n>```<n>### Response:<n>```cpp<n>int sum = 1; <n>for (int x = 1; x < size; ++x) <n>    sum += array[x];<n>const auto res = sum;<n>```<n>### Input<n>A program uses 31 bits each for positional and relocatable address spaces, and 4 bits<n>for segment limits. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Bob's feet hurt from running barefoot on the hot pavement.  I lost his shoes, didn't know where they landed, and had to run from the corner store to his home.  About where did he run? Choices:  A: a bed of nails B: town C: attractive consistent look D: city block E: ground<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* If you have no idea of the distance and only know the time, you can use the formulation $distance = time \cdot speed$<n>* You can add the distances if you have multiple times of the same travel like this, but do it at the end.<n>* Also, you don't need to do the formulation for each item, you can instead get all the times and divide by one of them if that makes a good unit of time.<n>* We use $miles/hours$ as the basis unless specified otherwise.<n>* The total miles he ran is =(10 times for town * 5 miles for town * 9 hours to run) + (15 times for attractive consist look * 1 mile for attractive consist look* 9 hours to run). This equals to: = (10 x 5) + (15 x 1). Since, the miles are in hours it equals to 12.5 plus 18.75 or 31.25. Since the rounding is to hundredths we have 31 miles which is close to 31.2. (Additionally when we say you lose something, we never know where it went)<n><n>#### Notes<n><n>* If you are given distance and have no idea of the time I can't give you this formula, you would need that formula to find the other.<n>* If there is no unit of time, I would not need that formula, and would probably need a list of all the distances you had to run as well.<n>* If you have one time of 20 minutes and know it was a distance of 5 miles and need to convert to a distance of 20 miles you just need to divide the two.<n><n>### Input 2<n><n>### Demorstration<n>Input: 100 meters away is a pile of horse manure. The average weight of a horse is 1,100 pounds. It is raining. It's going to rain for 5 hours a day, five days a week. Each cubic foot of horse manure weighs 45 pounds.  How much horse manure will pile up?<n>Answer: 6,200 cubic feet.<n>### Input 3: 2<n>We live in Canada. This winter will be warmer than average. Our drive

It will then ask the user to define a class with the string "Person" and it will ask if the person has the ability to cross street.  If the answer is true, then the Person class will be true.  If the answer to the initial question is false, the program will check if the Person class has an ability to do what the person did.  If the answer of what do you have is either a or b, then the Person class, will only ask if the person has an ability to stand upright. Choices: A) via the handlebars B) via a small chain connecting the wheel and crankset C) via the pedals D) via the seat<n><n>### Response<n><n>How does a bicycle pedal work? Choices: A): via the handlebars B): via a small chain connecting to the wheel and crankshaft. C): via pedals D): via a seat. In addition, if you use a bike pedal, be aware that it is designed to take the energy from your muscles and transfer it to the front wheel.  The cables of a bicycle pedals help in converting energy from the legs to a front wheel. The force applied to the pedals is transferred through rubber cables and then to the handlebars of a bicycle.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Behind what small door is canned goods usually kept?<n><n>### Instrument<n><n><n>### Examples<n><n>In a typical day, a person visits the office or school and sleeps at night. Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Bob and Boris were standing in a queue at the grocery store.  They were standing in place.  The line was fast, but the children in front of them were loud.   They were what? Choices:  A: frustration B: being annoyed C: delays D: irritation E: out of order<n><n>### Response:		Bob and Boris had an order.<n><n>### Input : <n>The baker has to bake 25 dozen sandwiches for a convention. He takes 14 minutes to bake the sandwiches and 9 minutes to cut them and serve them. How long does he need to bake before cutting and serving them?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Calculation:<n>Total minutes  = (25 * 14) + (25 * 9)<n>= 145 minutes<n><n>### Output : The baker needs 145 minutes to bake the 25 sandwiches<n><n>### Input<n>A group of 10 friends went to a restaurant. They ordered sandwiches, cake, coffee and apples. Each time the waiter takes the order, he writes it on a note.  As the waiter completes an order he puts that note on a piece of wood.  The waiter takes orders in the same order the notes get placed on the piece of wood.  What is the sequence by which the orders were delivered? What was the total cost of her food?<n><n>### Democracy -<n>Lila bought the 7 boxes of granol.<n>Her total cost for the granola is 7*0.5 is 3.5<n><n>Then she consumed 3 boxes.<n>Her total cost would be(3 boxes x 3 servings each) 9.<n><n>Then she bought  juice.<n>Her total cost is(20*0.1) is 0.2<n><n>Which is 9 + 0.2 is 9.2<n><n>Total cost = 9.2<n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity. A<n><n>### Solution Code<n><n>```<n>#!/usr/bin/python<n># -*- coding: utf-8 -*-<n><n># This task requires a simple logic. Input data and output answer<n><n>def main():<n>    # code goes here<n>    print("Adam buys 3 kilograms at supermarket and spends ", \<n>          "12+8 = 20")<n>    gym_hours = 2 * 60<n>    gym_price = 20<n>    plane_fuel_increase = gym_hours - 1<n>    plane_fueleprice = ((plane_fuel_in_crease * 2)) / 60<n>    <n>    print("Increased % of fuel = (" + \<n>        str(plane_fuel_increment) +"*2) / 60")<n>    print(plane_fueleprice)<n><n>if __name__ == "__main__":<n>    main()

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What would release energy, but not mainly in your muscles? Choices:  A: vent B: think C: shouting D: work off E: exercise<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A:<n><n>Vent is one of the ways to release energy. It is because that if you release the air from your lung from your belly, then the energy stored in the form of sound pressure is released. <n>The sound made in the air will bounce off your ears, and it may hurt you due to the pressure on your ears.<n><n>#### B:<n><n>Thinking is not a process in which energy is released. <n>When you are trying to solve the problem, your brain uses oxygen and glucose which is from the food you ate or the energy stored in your body. Your brain requires energy from chemical energy.  But think about this, how can you produce any sound from your brain. <n>Thus thinking doesn't produce energy. <n><n>#### C:<n><n>As we know, a shout is like a scream or yell, this noise needs to move the air in the throat to be produced. <n>The vocal cords vibrate in air, and the air pressure causes the sound to spread through the medium.  Thus if you shout, you will release energy to produce the noise.<n><n>#### D:<n><n>Work off is not the main way to release energy. As a definition,  work-off is a physical activity that uses muscular force to use energy. <n>Thus from the definition, we can see that it is not about releasing energy to the full extent. It's a way that people use muscle force, so it is just one of the ways to consume energy.<n><n>#### E:<n><n>Exercising is not necessarily a main way to release energy, because when you exercise, you are using energy to exercise, and you are not just releasing energy. <n>For example, during the exercise, your heart will beat faster to supply more oxygen (which contains energy) to your body. <n>The process of taking in the oxygen and converting it to glucose is using energy. So if you exercise regularly, you will use more energy than if work-off does.<n><n><n>### Input (part2):<n>You are taking a group of 14 people for a tour through the city. Each tour guide will charge you 60 dollars for each person. If one of your group becomes ill, you will be charged a 10% addition fee per person's service. You have budget

Choices:  A: accomplish B: learn about C: money D: notoriety E: religion<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer:<n>    > A)<n>        <n>#### Details:<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Below is a graphical representation of how a particular web service interacts with another web service. Identify and describe the function of each box.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer:<n><n>#### Details:<n>In order to process payments using the C2P service, we have to create an app, and then register it by setting the AppID key and value of “abcdef”. A ClientID is created, which is then used for each of the transactions.<n>Firstly, an initial call is made to create the app, in order to generate the AppID, ClientID, and the CACert URL where the private key is. Then we need to create a call to generate a new JWT. This is a hashed representation of the data on the web request. This is used for authentication, where each client is authenticated by checking the hash in the response returned by the JWT generation. If the hashed value is successfully verified in the payment, then the request will be authenticated, allowing payment. After the client is authenticated, the process checks that the payment amount is not above a set limit, and then the customer information is checked to ensure that only known clients are allowed via the app id.<n><n>#### Solution:<n>As a first step, an application is created in the C2P web portal. The information entered into this step will remain the same as the information required for the API calls. To create an application, we require an ApplicationID and a ClientKey. They create a “new” application for the purposes of this example, and enter the ID “abcdef” (the same value as we would need to set for our API calls) and a ClientKey of “0”.<n><n>Once an application is built, the next step is to generate API keys for individual use. When we create an application, we are given 2 keys, the ClientKey, and the AppID. The AppID is our application, which we are creating here for our API calls, and must be set each time to an appropriate value. This value is set in the API calls as the AppID variable and must be the same for all API calls made, including the original application call, as well as for the JWT generation when we generate our JWT signature to pass to the C2P Service.<n><n>API keys are used to pass

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:How does a flea locomote? Choices:  A: attack B: suck blood C: stay D: lay eggs E: jump<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: How does a flea locome? Choices: A: attack, B: suck blood, C: stay,  D: lay eggs, E: jump<n><n>```python<n># -*- coding: utf-8 -*-<n><n>from collections import Counter<n>from.scraper import scrape<n><n># Main<n>def main():<n>    # Get the text<n>    text = scrape('https://data.stackexchange.com/scifi/query/689044/fleas')[0]<n><n>    # Get the key<n>    key = text.find('</div>') + text.find('div>')<n><n>    # Get list of words<n>    words = text[key:].split()<n><n>    # Generate answer by sorting the list<n>    words.sort()<n><n>    # Get number of answer<n>    answers = len(words)<n><n>    # Generating text description<n>    for index in range(0, answers):<n>        description = ''<n>        description += f'In what way does a flea move? Choices: '<n><n>        if index == 0:<n>            if words[index] == 'A':<n>                description += 'A: '<n><n>        else:<n>            if words[-(index + 1)] == 'A':<n><n>                description += 'B: '<n><n>        description += f"""<n>            {f'A:{words[index]:<30} B:{words[-(index + 2)]:<30} C:{words[-(index+3)]:<30}'}"""<n><n>    print(description)<n><n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    main()<n>```<n>

Think about an object, which has two qualities/conditions.<n><n>The correct answer is "I was not surprised with what Joe said", which means that Joe's condition/quality is "away from" what Sam said.<n><n>I did not write the correct response of this task. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some large pieces of paper that are not for sale? Choices:  A: cabinet B: computer printer C: suitcase D: office supply store E: artist's studio<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a program in JavaScript, with one function, named guess_purchases, which solves a word problem given in the instructions above.<n><n>You will be provided the number of times a particular word is used in a string. Use these counts to create a guess and a range for the price. The user will then guess what the purchase is and you should check if the guess is a valid purchase.<n>For example, the user will guess 3 for the number of pieces of paper purchased. You will then check the original string for how many times each word is used in the string. If the number of each word that is in the original string is in the range of the user's guess, then the guess is valid, if not, it is not valid. 3 times the word 'paper' does not appear in the string given.<n>The first time the word 'paper' gets used in the string, it must be guessed again.  The original string was "I need three large pieces of paper" so the user should guess "three" again, and now your program will ask for a guess again. This keeps happening until the user correctly guesses the number of pieces of 'paper' used in the string.<n><n>The solution you should implement:<n>- Take the string that was provided as input:<n>  - Remove the word "pieces", and return a new string: "I need {0} large ".<n>  - Remove the first word in your returned string:  " large ".<n>- Create a variable 'guess_count' and use it as your guess for the number of pieces in the original string. This must be done until the user correctly guessed how many pieces are in the string.<n>- If the number of times "paper" got used in the given string's string, and "guess_count" are in the same range:<n>  - Set the flag to true.<n>  - Return "correct", otherwise:<n>  - Return "incorrect".<n><n>### Instructor:<n>Create a method inside the function called guess_purchases() that will remove the first and last 4 letters of a word from a string. For your first attempt it is highly recommended that you use substring to accomplish this. However, you may use another method of your own choosing, so long as your method uses strings to manipulate string values.<n><n>### Inputs
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Why would professionals playing sports not be able to compete? Choices:  A: pain B: mudslide C: sweating D: injuries E: rain<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input<n><n><p>James has to refuel his boat. It used to cost $100 to refill his tank. He got an extra tank and fuel prices increased by 20%. How much does he pay to refuel?</p><n><p>Choice E (5x$105)</p><n><n>### Response<n>Input: James has a 5-day week and 2 different activities that he participates in one hour each day.<n>How many hours a week does he spend on each activity? (Assume James only does one activity on a day if that is the only time he participates.)<n><n>Answer: A 2:2:1<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>If a basketball player goes to the gym each day for 1 hour, 3 days a week then they spend 3 or 360 hours in the gym each year. To be a professional player they may have to practice for 30 hours more every week which equals 1200 extra hours for the year not including the time they have in the game. If they have free time they could also spend an extra 1900 hours studying the game. So a professional basketball player dedicates almost 2460 hours playing basketball each year.

A) unfeeling B) negligent C) antipathy D) indifferent E) rapport<n><n>Another person who doesn't care someone and wishes they fail is an unfeeling person, and that

Counting is one of the things that is illegal. This can cause the casino to get the amount of winning and cheats.<n><n>### Input<n>Write a program that reads a string s of lowercase letters and returns the number of strings (w) that can be written from s to the terminal with the number of letters (N) in each string at most 1000.<n><n>Input:   s = "abc" n = 1000<n>Output:    w = 3<n><n>### Response<n><n>1. w = (1000-2)/3 = 333.33 = 3<n><n>2. w = n/2<n><n>### Additonal Response<n><n>1. The way of using the for loop is simple and also easy for programmers to understand. Thus, using for loop is good.<n><n>2. We can also use recursion. But recursively, it is harder and take much more memory than for-loop approach.

If the user does not say what you think was going to be said, they will be told that you think they did not say the correct thing.<n><n>If they do, we will print the statement they actually made to the console and congratulate them.<n><n>### Example:<n>User says "Joe did it"<n>You should say "Yes, I was correct."<n>If we print "Joe did it," we will also be asked what we thought of the next response. If the response is "Yes." and "I was correct." we have successfully answered the question.<n><n>If we attempt to print, "Your first name, what did you think is going to happen next?", we will attempt to print the entire user input to the console and throw an error. The problem here is that there are too many variables and it does not know how to take these and print it to the console.<n><n>### Solution<n>We add
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The college kids weren't known for their apartment decor choices, they used a folding chair inside their what? Choices:  A: bathroom B: closet C: school D: room E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>Let's make a quick list:<n>- We've got: College, Kids, What?, Choices, A, B, C, D, E<n>- We'll use Counter as our Lists Class.  Here is how the class looks:<n>```typescript<n>import { Counter } from "../counter";<n><n>export class KidsLists extends Counter {<n>    constructor(public what: string, options: any[]) {<n>        super();<n>        this.options = options;<n>    }<n>    getOptions() {<n>        // the options property was given to us, but let's also create the properties ourselves<n>        let optionsLength: number = super.getOptions().length;<n>        console.log("optionsLength", optionsLength);<n>        if(optionsLength === 0) {<n>            throw new Error("No options were provided")<n>        }<n>        // this will be the same object every time for this class.  When the object is new it will equal undefined though<n>        this.defaultOptions = {<n>            A: undefined,<n>            B: undefined,<n>            C: undefined,<n>            D: undefined,<n>            E: undefined<n>        };<n>        return this.defaultOptions;<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n>- We're now going to loop over the options provided. Each time we loop we're going to check if our options are undefined, and, if so, we're going to assign the default.<n>```javascript<n>const defaultOptions = {<n>    A: 'bathroom',<n>    B: 'closet',<n>    C:'school',<n>    D: 'room',<n>    E: 'church'<n>}.values() as any[];<n><n>class KidsLists extends Lists {<n>    public what: string;<n>    public options: any[];<n>    private defaultOptions: any[];<n><n>    constructor(a: any) {<n>        super();      // the default options<n>        // let's use the constructor to get the options for the class<n>        const options = <any>a;<n>        return this;<n>    }<n><n>    public getOptions() {<n>    // let's get the options we've been given<n>        return this.options;<n>    }<n>```<n>- Let's check out the options from our class:<n>```javascript<n>//

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.
