Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The star had 4 rocky planets and 4 gaseous planets orbiting it, what was it part of Choices:  A: hollywood B: night sky C: constellation D: aliens E: solar system<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: Hollywood<n><n>### Input<n>```text<n>Adam likes to cook a great meal, but he does not like to clean up after himself.  His kitchen is organized into six pantries with a total of 18 shelves and 88 plates.  He would like to organize his kitchen by color.  How many plates does he have that are orange? In this scenario, use a binary search.<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>```text<n>3430<n>```<n><n>`25365461121312310181392<n>```<n><n>The first test for 25365 is<n>```text<n>25365 == 2536<n>```<n>which returns 0 so the next test is...<n>```text<n>26405 == 2540<n>```<n>which returns false so the first choice is false so there's another 3/4 test and the binary search is at 21/2 = 11.<n><n>### Input <n>```text<n>James, Kesha and Kwame lived in a 2 bedroom apartment.  One week they discovered there was an extra bedroom attached to the apartment that they never noticed or knew about. Their apartment just so happened to be located in New York, where the cost of rental living has been on the rise for the last 5 years.  They got the 2 bedroom apt for $1200. How much will they be paying for the new, third bedroom?<n>```<n><n>## Response<n>```text<n>$1709.2<n>```<n><n>First, the initial price of $1200 is the midpoint of the range $1100 - $1500. There are four items in the range of choice, so each item can be tested in 2 possible positions. There is a good chance that each item is equally likely to be chosen by a given user, and there's only a 1 in 4 chance of each item being chosen. The first choice for a list of four items is $1200 and we do that test here, and we go to the next choice, $1500 and do the test there.<n>To make this a binary search, we can

You’re to build the following features:(Chooses all options that apply, but does not choose) The column heading should read ‘Day’ and the data type should be Date The column heading should read ’Year’ and the data type of integer The column heading should read ”Month” and the data type should also be number The column heading should read “Date” and the data type of date. Your columns will be numbered 2 through 5. The column heading should read "Taken" and the data type for this column should be a number between 1 and 6. The last column should be named "Total" and the data type should again be a number. Your calculation should be based on the total for days taken in the "taken" column divided by 7 days to get the daily value, then added up for the total.  After your first day, multiply the number in the taken column by 2. In the total column add the total taken divided by 2 and  the sum of the total taken.

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:People always talked childlike to him, even though his disability was physical and didn't affect his what? Choices:  A: strength B: brain C: potential D: qualification E: competence<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Code:<n>```javascript<n>var people = 'people';<n>if (people == true) {<n>    console.log ('This people speaks truthfully. '); <n>} else {<n>    console.err ('This people is lying. ');<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>```console<n>Lying.<n>```

Choices:  A: pets B: fills the pond C: attempt to fly D: school together E: breath in water<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explication:It costs 6 times more to buy food for a pond of 1 million fish than it would for 1 million dogs. Because each fish only needs to feed every couple of weeks it's more cost effective to feed a large number of fish.<n><n>### Input<n>How much would you have to pay for a plane that can travel at subsonic speed?<n><n>### Input A:The plane is capable of subsonic speeds, but never goes that fast. Answer is B<n><n>### Input B:Sadly, the plane burns expensive fuel. Answer is A<n><n>### Input C:If it would fly at supersonic speeds it would have to be a rocket<n><n>### Response<n>B <n><n>### Explixition:There are four possible answers. The plane is capable of sub sonic speeds, but does not. The plane is not capable of subsonic travel (it is a rocket) the plane travels slower than sub sonic speeds (Airplanes fly about 20 knots. In knots that is about 200 nautial miles per hour. Subsonic is anything faster than that) and the plane travels slowly enough that it needs to carry fuel that is more expensive than regular airplane fuel.<n> <n>### Input: They want me to complete an addition problem, but they don't tell me what to add. Two major parties want to put their contribution to the new currency. But how does the new currency know whether these contributors are honest or not?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input : Adam wants to contribute 30% of all Bitcoins and Mark wants to contribute 45% of all Bitcoin. As a result, the new currency is valued at 52.5<n><n>Input : Adam contributes 20% of all Bitcosins but Mark contributes 85%. As a result, the value of the new currency goes to only 0.5.<n><n>### Input : A new crypto currency is created with a total of 500 units.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>Fraudster<n><n>A: 400 units: Adam contributed $400 and fraudster contributed $100<n><n>B: 150 units: Fraudster contributes $350 and Adam contributes 10<n><n>### Question :<n><n>How much will the new currency value?<n><n>### Answer :<n><n>C<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>Answer C is the easiest to understand. The new created currency was $350 worth. We know Adam contributed $399 and the fraudster contributed 10, which make A and B the other two choices respectively. If the new currency is worth $350, then the value for one  unit is $350/500 = $0.70. So Adam contributed $390 (390X$0.70 = $279) and fraudster contributed 0.1 (0.1X$0.7 = $0.07).<n><n>D<n><n>### Exaplanation :<n><n>For answer D, I don't think it's the best choice. We are trying to find the value for one unit. Since the total amount of the currency is $500, $100 contributed by the fra

The run time<n><n>Outputs should be the same as follows:  <n>Sample Output :  3:44:40  <n>Sample Input :  2:44:45  <n>Sample output:  1:00:00  <n><n><n>### Instrucciones<n>Escriba un programa que aceptará entrada y mostrará los valores de acuerdo con las instrucciones que se le proporcionan.<n>Las entradas deben ser ingresadas por el usuario y la salida se debe imprimir.<n>Desde los ejemplos de salida, deben estar impresos en el mismo formato que explican las instrucciones.<n>Input en el mismo formato:  <n><n>1. La hora es el número:<n>2. El número de manos:  <n>3. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where do you watch garbage? Choices:  A: television B: dumpster C: landfill D: fox news E: trashcan<n><n>### Response:		The letter C is correct.<n><n>### Solution:<n>The answer is option B, C or D.<n><n>- A: Television is a type of media where information is presented through the screen or display in many ways.<n><n>- B: Dumpster is a container for waste.<n><n>- C: A landfill is a place where waste is disposed of.<n><n>- D: Fox News is a conservative American cable news television channel.<n><n>- E: A trash can is a container for holding waste material or rubbish.<n><n>### Input : Why are you late? Choices: A: you left your wallet behind B: you did not bring a jacket C: you forgot to charge your car D: you got caught in traffic<n><n>### Result:<n>A<n><n>### Solution<n>A answer is correct as it is the reason of the being late.<n><n>- B answer is incorrect as it is not one of the reasons that make you late.<n><n>- C answer should not be the answer as the question says “Why are you late” not “What made you late”.<n><n>- D answer should not be the main answer because it is a reason that happened after getting late.<n><n>### Submission<n>```python<n>def solution(input):<n>	if 'A' in input:<n>		return 'A'<n>	if 'B' in input:<n>        	return 'B'<n>	if 'C' in input:<n>                return 'C'<n>	if 'D' in input:<n>           	return 'D'<n>	if 'E' in input:<n>       		return 'E'<n>	else:<n>		return input.split(" ")[1][0]<n>```<n><n>### Solution explanation<n><n>- Input:Where do you want to go on holiday? Choices:  R: Rome B: Barcelona C: Boston D: Budapest E: Berlin F: Florence G: Geneva H: Hawaii<n><n>- Response:<n><n>Letters starting from A – E indicate the location of the holiday and H is the ending letter. <n>Letters starting from F – P is the city name which is the letter after location<n>Letters starting from R – Z are the country name<n><n>- Input: I’m planning to study at MIT. R: Rome B: Boston C: Barcelona D: Berlin

Choices:  A: planet B: basin C: submarines D: earth E: pacific<n><n>### Response:		D   <n><n>### Input :How long does it take for Saturn to orbit the sun? Choices:  D: 23 years <n><n>Response: A<n><n>### Input<n>Input 1: A plane from Mexico to California has a total flight time of 2 hours.  The plane flies straight at 100 miles per hour. How long does the plane travel on the ground to or from its destination?<n>Input 2: A plane from Texas to Mexico has a total flight time between 3.5 and 6 hours, depending on the aircraft’s speed.  The plane fights at about 50 miles per hour on average, which is slower than most planes.  What distance will be covered in a six-hour flight?<n><n>### Response<n>In plane, distance to destination is same no matter how long total flight time is.<n>

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What does exercising immediately lead to? Choices:  A: relaxation B: exhaustion C: energetic D: become stronger E: use energy<n><n>### Response:		<n>A) relaxation<n><n>### Instructions:Enter your response or code. If you do not know what to do, enter the letter 'e'. You can use as many lines as you want to type your response:<n><n>### Demission:<n>Input:  A: relax<n><n>### Instuction:<n>What is the relationship between exercise and energy? Choose one of the answer choices and write your response below. You may leave this question blank.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>a) Exercise causes energy to increase. <n>b) Energy causes exercises to increase.<n><n>### Response/Answer:<n>b) Energy causes exercise to increase.<n><n>---<n>### Instruptions:<n>If you need help figuring out the solution, you may click here.<n>```python<n><n>#!/usr/bin/python3<n><n><n>def Exercising(d):<n>	if str(d) == "relax":<n>		return "A"<n>	else:<n>		return ""<n>	<n><n>def Relaxing(e):<n>	if str([1,3,5]) == "6":<n>		str("B")<n>else:<n>	return ""<n><n>exercise = input("Exercise your choice here: ")<n>Exercise(exercise)<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:She wanted to make a quilt of velvet, where should she look? Choices:  A: grandma B: clothing C: jewelry store D: clothes E: fabric store<n><n>### Response:		<n>### (Answer from E.)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Now we are going to create a function that will print all possible combos in a list.<n><n>### Inputs<n>I have a set of two lists and I would like to know the number of possible permutations the first can form from the second.<n><n>List 1: [0,1,2,3]<n><n>List 2: [3,0,2,1,4]<n> <n><n>### Expected Output <n> <n>Output 1: [0][1][2][3]<n>Output 2: [0][1]<n>Output 3: [0] <n>Output 4: [1]  <n>Output 5: [2][3]  <n>Output 6: [2][3][1]<n>Output7: [2][3]` <n>and so on.<n><n>- If you run this on the first input, it should print the following:<n>  - [0][1][3][2]<n>  - [1][4][3][0]<n>  - [0]<n>  - []<n>  - ["3"]<n><n>### Notes:<n>1. The main part is to print the elements of the list in alphabetical order(and not in the order of input).<n>2. In each iteration of function i should start from index(0) to index(length of list-1)<n><n>- [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/VKgCe.png<n><n>### Code:<n>```<n>def p_perms(l1,l2)<n><n>#I will use the following lists below<n><n>l_1 = ["0","1","2","3"]<n>l_2 = ["3","0","2","1","4"]<n><n>num_perms = 0<n>for i in range(len(l_1)):<n>        lst = l1[:i] + l_2[i:i+1]<n>        list_of_perms_from_i = lst<n>        for j in list_of_perems_from_i:<n>            print(str(j))<n>```<n>```<n>**Output**:<n>0<n>1<n>2<n>3<n>0<n>1<n>3<n>2<n>4<n>0<n>1<n>0<n>4<n>2<n>

A maze is a path that connects the start to any other location. Each list of `(x, y)` coordinates can be considered as a path

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What type of person typically contracts illness? Choices:  A: hospital B: head C: sick person D: elderly person E: doctor's office<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```ruby<n>    if illness.size == 3<n>      put "A: the hospital."<n>    elsif illness.size ==1<n>      puts "B: head"<n>    elsif ill = illness.size ==2<n>      puts "C: the sick person"<n>    elsif ilness.size == 4<n>      put "D: the elderly person"<n>      end<n>     ...<n>```<n><n>### Instructions: <n><n>## Demo 2: Use recursion to solve this problem.<n><n>```ruby<n>ruby<n>    def factorial(n)<n>       if n > 1<n>         n * factorial(n-1)<n>       else<n>         0<n>       end<n><n>    end<n><n>    factorial(5)<n>    puts 4<n><n>```<n>

Choices:  A: make breakfast B: go hiking C: pack or bag D: light fire E: grab a match<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input<n>>what would a camper need before he or she can do a task: cook food?<n><n>### Response<n>>I can provide your requirement that you do for cooking food.<n>In order to cook food you have to light a fire for that you need a match, that is why option E is the right answer.<n><n>### Input/Demostration<n>>Why is 47 = 4 + 4 + 4?<n><n>### Answer<n>>Because 4+4+4=47<n><n>### Input /Demonstration<n>>How much does a watermelon weigh?<n>2<n><n>### Answer:<n>>3<n><n>```shell<n>48 kg<n>```<n><n>```python<n>2 kg of watermelon<n>```<n><n>### Demostration/Input<n>>Does 538 * 83 = 44,984?<n><n>## Input <n>>Does  538 * 183 = 99,774?<n><n>## Demonstration <n>>No the correct answer is <n>```python<n>99,770<n>```<n>### Demo<n>```shell<n>538 * 63 = 34,414<n>```<n><n>```Python<n>538 *3 = 1,612<n><n>5 + 3 + 8 = 17<n>```<n><n>```JavaScript<n>5 *3 =15<n>```<n># Challenge: Complete all of the below tasks. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The man was eating lunch, but rushed when he looked at his watch, why did he rush? Choices:  A: gain weight B: late for work C: heartburn D: bad breath E: early for work<n><n>### Response:		<n>"He got heartburn"<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Spoof is a function that takes the user response and creates a response of the given type. Use _Spoof_ with appropriate calls.<n><n>### Requirements:<n>Spoof should pass in a _choice_ parameter. It should call the _ChoiceSpoof_ function and return a _choice_ parameter that matches the requested choice.<n><n>### Implementation:<n>``` cpp<n>// SPOOF.C<n>// -*- C++ -*-<n>#include "Spoof.h"<n><n><n>// Include the standard library<n>#include <iostream><n>#include <conio.h><n><n><n>// Includes<n>#include "Stub.h"<n>#include "ChoiceSpoof.hxx"<n>#include "CommandSpoof.hxtx"<n><n><n>// Defines<n>const int LINE_LENGTH = 50;<n><n><n>// Spoof main function<n>int Spoof(struct choice cCh[], int n) <n>{<n>    // Return status<n>    int iReturn = STM_NOT_SATISFIED;<n>    // Check for input<n>    switch ( cCh[ cCh[n].ch_index ].choice)<n>    {<n>        // Choice - 1:<n>        case '1':<n>            std::cout << choiceSp[std::cout << "You answered 1" << std::endl;<n>            iReturn = STMSTATUS;<n>            break;<n><n>        // Choice 6:<n>        case '6':<n>            std::cin.clear();<n>            std::cin >> std::number_input;<n>            // Call Stub with _no_ input<n><n>            std::cout<n>                << "Stub received input. " << std::endl<n>                << "You should get a prompt for input." << std::endl;  <n>            break;<n>        // Case Choice - 6:<n>        default:<n>            std::cout <n>                << choice[cCh[cCh[n].ch].choice] << " is not a valid choice" <n>                <<std::endl;<n>            return ChoiceSpoof(_choose);<n><n>    });<n><n>    return iReturn;<n>}<n><n><n>// ChoiceSpoof

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Sally lost her kite because she wasn't careful.  She thought that there was more string on the spool, but it slipped out of her fingers when she reached the what?. Choices:  A: child's hand B: the last straw C: hobby shop D: end of line E: toy store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n>You are the manager of a fast food restaurant. In order to increase business, you would like to determine how many people order fast food while they are traveling.<n><n>#### Instructions:<n>For this problem, you will need to consider all traveling patterns<n>between the hours of 3:00 PM and 9:00 PM for 13 days<n>and determine how often customers purchase a sandwich in a given amount of time.<n><n>#### Demonstration: Consider the following table:<n><n>#### Instrucrtion:<n>* How often do customers place an order while driving in both directions on a weekday (Sunday through Friday) within the specified amount of time?<n>* Include the results in a graph or table. *<n><n>#### Solution:<n><n>### Input<n><n>How often do customers place an orders while driving in both directions during these 13 days? <n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Consider the following table:<n>Input:   <n><n>### Output<n>The results should be written in a table or graph.<n>* The number of days in each week is given as a list of integers between Sunday and Friday.  The total number of days is equal to sum of the values in this list of 1 to 7.<n>* On Sunday, Tuesday and Thursday, customers can drive in both directions.  On Monday and Wednesday, customers can drive exclusively in one direction.  On Fridays, the store is closed.<n>* The number that appears in each row of this table indicates how often a person placed an order.<n>* The table should indicate the day of the week and the direction in which a customer is driving at each time.<n><n><n><n>### Input and output<n>

If the user input is outside the range it will print "Invalid number".<n>\### Demonstrate:<n>\### Question: Is the code below is or is not correct?<n>\### Code: The following code only takes input that is between 1 and 99, and if the input is not between 1 and 2, it will print "Invalid".<n>\### Annoyer: I had no idea you were still there.<n><n>### Input 1: A: I got your email, I have been waiting for you.<n><n>### A: I got your text. Choices:  A: winners and losers B: perform better C: might win D: losses E: enemies<n><n>### Response:		<n>Your response should be similar in structure to the example above.<n><n>### Input<n>I have a 5-year old son and a 3-year old daughter.  The kids ask me how long they can enjoy our vacation.  If I want them to remember this day for a long time, how should I answer them in a week and in a year?<n><n>### Response<n>My response uses `if` statements to structure code.<n><n>### If a statement<n>Let's go on a vacation for a week<n>It will be very long in the future<n><n>### If statements<n>1.<n>We will go on a vacation in a week<n><n>### If statement<n>1. We will go on a vacations in a month<n>3. We are not going soon<n>2.<n>3. We will go on the vacations<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Let's go to a beach in summer. We'll go on it for a week and a weekend is always on Sunday. How many Sundays are in a year?
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What could prevent someone from buying chistmas presents? Choices:  A: happiness B: lack of money C: stress D: relief E: exhiliration<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input:(A + B)! = ((A x B)! A B = 25, A=2 B =2<n><n>### Response:(2^2)5  = 32 = C=64<n><n>### Instructions:(A * 4!2) * 4 = 160 answer:d<n><n>### Input:: The current of river is 5 miles per hour; the boat makes 4 miles per hour downstream and 5 miles per hour upstream. How far can the motorboat go in 6 hours down stream?<n><n>### Response:: 8 miles<n><n>### Input=36*3=?<n>### Response: 108<n><n>### Input(27+98)/3<n>### Response:41<n><n><n>### Input = 5!/3<n>### Response = 15<n><n>#### Input: A bag contains a red, a blue, and a yellow pen. You cannot tell the colors without looking inside. Select a pen, then turn it over. Now you can see the color. If you pick a pen at random (with no replacement - the rule that says no matter how many times you draw a card, the same card won't be drawn twice) what is the probability that the color of the pen you drew was red?<n><n>### Answer: 40%<n><n><n>### Answer = 10/2<n><n><n>### The length x and width of a rectangular room are both in inches. What is the area in square inches?<n><n>### Area = sqrt(l^2 + w^2)  - sqrt(l^4 + w^4)<n>### Response: Area = sqrt(64 + 49) - sqrt(64x(64))  = 49<n><n><n>### Your father is taller than you, but you are definitely taller than your mother. Suppose you are 5 and 1/2 feet tall. Then how much taller is your mother than your little brother (who is 4 feet tall)?<n><n>### Response : 2+1/2  =3/2  --> 5ft/1 1/2 = 5  - 4 =5<n><n><n>

Many British cities and tourist spots have them.  They are also conveniently located near city train stations and at major airports and train stations in London. The London Metro underground system has telephone booths, which is useful for tourists since it gives them access to the city without needing a cell phone plan.<n><n>#### Notes:<n><n>* Choices should not be presented to the user in random order.<n>* The instruction and demonstration do not need to mention the same answer options.<n><n>----

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:How might a person address someone who is leaving? Choices:  A: further cause B: wave goodbye C: attempt suicide D: insulting them E: thank god<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Due process of law should not provide a person the right to commit suicide. Insulting them would be inadequate, as insulting a person is not to cause them leave. They will simply insult right back which would be a pointless activity. They will also not attempt suicide either due to the law stating they have no right to do so. Thus the best explanation is E, which is thanking them for leaving.<n><n>### Input A:How many square units does a 6 feet by 6 feet square have? How would you write the area? Choices: A: 36; B: 36 sq ft; C: 336 ft sq; D: 36 ft sq; E: 2160 sq ft<n><n>### Response A:<n><n>### Explaneation A:<n>6 square feet gives the answer of 36 square feet. This is due to the unit is square feet.<n><n>### Response B:How many square units do a 5 feet by 5 feet square have? How could you write the area?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>### Explnaeon B:<n>5 feet by 5 ft equals 25 feet square. This is due to sq refers to 25'^2<n><n>### Input C:How large is a cube shaped object with a 2ft edge? How might a person write its area? Choices: C: 432 square inches; D: 432 sq ft; E: 4324 sq in<n><n>### Response C:<n><n>### Explaination C:<n>The object should be 2ft by 2ft by 9ft to have a total area of 432 square feet. However, to write the area, the person would write 432 sq feet due to the s to the word sq as in 432 sq. <n><n>### Response D:How big is a pyramid shaped object with a base that measures 4ft square area? How might a person calculate its volume?<n>Answer: 99999 cubic feet<n><n>### Explepnaon D:<n>A pyramid object with a 4ft square base with a height of 235ft would be

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:John enjoyed his time visiting the museum.  He wanted to spend more time there, so that he could study the exhibits more.   He was a very academic person and loved doing what? Choices:  A: tired feet B: gaining knowledge C: back pain D: being bored E: pondering<n><n>### Response:		<n>We are looking for the single word (verb) that "John" enjoys more, rather than a noun. (tired feet, knowing, etc.).<n><n>### Input : John is a hard worker.  He works on a construction project 95% of the time on weekdays as a contractor.  He also worked on weekends 33% of the time as a volunteer.  What percentage of his week doe he work?<n><n>### Response : The answer should be a decimal value of some sort. For example:<n><n>```<n>> 9.8    =>  he worked 100% of the week.  <n>> 0.0    =>  he didn't work.    <n>> 0.2    =>  he worked ~22% of the week.<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>John enjoyed his time visit. He wanted to spend some more time there to study his subject more.   He is very academic person and he enjoys what?<n><n>### Response<n>The answer should be one of the verbs.  John is a verb person, not a noun person. (eg.  knowing)<n><n>### Input John enjoyed his time visit and wanted to spend sometime more to study his subject more. He is a very academic person and he loves -<n>### Response<n>We like answers that have the right verb, rather than a nub (to ponder).<n><n>### Input 1: John enjoyed his time visit to the museum; he wanted spend more time there to study the exhibits more; he is a very academic person who wants do ___?_<n>### Input 2: John enjoyed his time travels; but he wanted to spend more time studying languages, culture, etc. he wanted to study __?_<n>### Response<n>An answer that is correct would be...<n><n>```<n>- travels (not travel)<n>- time<n>```<n><n>## Input<n>### Output<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What would an adult man do to get ready for work? Choices:  A: dress herself B: shower C: dress himself D: drink beer E: drive train<n><n>### Response:		Write the word or phrase that best completes the request. Provide the response as the output for the question.<n><n>## The solution<n>Solution:<n>```<n>public class Solution {<n>    public List<String> GetAllPermutation(ReadOnlyRoman Numeral) {<n>        int n=Numeral.Length-1;<n>        ArrayList alist=new ArrayList();<n>        int count=0;<n>        for(int i=count;i<n;i++){<n>            ArrayList temp = GetAllPermmutations(Numeral[count+1..n-1]);<n>            ArrayList aux = new ArrayList();<n>            ArrayList aux_temp = new ArrayList();<n>            <n>            for(int j=0;j<n;j++){<n>                for (Integer aux_num:aux) {<n>                    aux_temp.add(aux_num+Numeral[j]);<n>                    aux.add(aux_temp.size()-1);<n>                    aux_num=aux_temp.size();<n>                }<n>            }<n>            alist.addAll(aux);<n>        }<n>        for(int x:alist) System.out.print(x);<n>        return alist;<n>    }<n>    private ArrayList GetAllPermmutations (int n){<n>        ArrayList temp = new ArrayList();<n>        for(int j=1;j<=n;j++){<n>            Integer count = new Integer(j);<n>            Integer aux = new Integer(count);<n>            for (int k=2;k<=n;k++) {<n>                if(Integer.toString((k-1) % Integer.parseInt(count)).equals(Integer.toString(n-1)%Integer.parseInt(count))){<n>                    temp.add(count+Integer.toString(n)+Integer.toString((k)));<n>                }<n>                if(Integer <n*1000> <= Integer.toString((k-2)%Integer.parseInt((n-1)))){<n>                }<n>                Integer.next();<n>                }<n>                <n>        }<n><n>        return temp;<n>    }<n>}<n>```

The output does *not* specify how much time is spent. For example, if the user spends 2 hours on cardio, they could easily spend 1 hour doing actual exercise.<n><n>The output format would look something like this:<n><n>```<n>Categories:<n><n>Cardio 2 times<n><n>Lifting Weights 2 times<n><n>Total Hours = 4<n>```<n><n>For example, if the user spent 1 hour on cardio and 3 hours working out with weights, the output would be:<n><n>```<n>Cardio 1 hour<n><n>Lifting Weight 3 hours<n><n>Total Hours: 4<n>```<n>

The first step is to make your decision which food or exercise you want to do next. The second step is where you are going to go, run, or take your food. The 2:20 minute step is where you do what you said you would do. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:If I have a vintage, decorative light source in my possession, what is it likely to be? Choices:  A: sun B: sky C: candle D: house E: lamp<n><n>### Response:		Which options do you think is the most likely?<n><n>### Input:(If you need more context, look at the code)<n><n>### Response<n>C.<n>There are 10 questions in this assessment. This is the fifth question. Your response can be formatted as text or as code.<n><n>This code shows an animation of a spinning cube. What does it do?<n>### Input:This is the code of a spinning cube<n><n>### Response:"<n>This code draws a spinning cube. The cube rotates constantly 360 degrees a minute. The rotation rate is given the rate number. The rotation rate is a property of a cube named `rate`. The rotation rate determines how fast the cube is spinning. There are other ways to think about it. The higher the rotation rate, the faster the cube moves. And if a cube has a rate of 0, then the cube will not spin at<n>all. So rotation rate goes from a value of 0 to 60 in this cube. For each<n>repeating loop, the cube draws a rotation point to place one pixel on the<n>cube. It rotates the cube using the rotation rate.<n>The next statement uses the `drawRotPoint` function. The code inside the curly braces defines what is happening. The `drawRotPoint`<n>function takes two values.<n><n>The first value is an angle. The `rotAt` argument receives this angle. This<n>variable receives an angle from 0 to the value of that cube's rotation rate. The<n>default rotation is 45. In `rotAt`, the base is zero, like before, but the<n>rotation is always rounded up to another degree.<n>The second value is an offset. The `offset` is the amount of each rotation is.<n>It is represented by an integer and counts for one pixel.<n><n>To the right of `offset`, the code assigns the rotation to the `rotAt`<n>argument. This will move each rotation point by one pixel. After drawing the<n>cube once, it then draws another rotation point. It then restarts the<n>`for` loop which draws another rotation point and so on. It continues to do<n>this until the `for` loop reaches the end of its code segment. This will<n>cause the cube to never stop drawing rotation points. It draws these<n>movements

The “Person” class will keep track of all information about the person. Below is sample output and information about your class.<n><n>### Class:<n>The Person Class<n>    __init__(self, name: str, age: int, favorite_color: str = 'none', birthday: datetime = None, height: float = 1.70, weight: float = 79.0, favorite_food: str = 'none')<n>    def __str__(self):<n>        return f'Hi, my name is {self.name}. I\'m {self.age} years old.'<n><n>### Sample Output:<n>Hi, my name is David. I’m 32 years old.<n>Hi, my name John. I’m 26 years old.<n>Hi! My name is Anna. I’m 9 years old.<n>Hi my name is 10<n><n>### Instructions:<n>> Add a method to the Person class that accepts an argument “height.” This method will return the person’s weight relative to their height, such that a new value is only returned if the person has changed.<n>Output:<n>> Hi! Choices:  A: new york B: concert C: tv studio D: gig E: recording studio<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:  D and E<n><n>- A is very likely, but B, C, and D are also likely.<n>- E is very likely but D and E are also likely.<n><n>### Input A:You are building a new room in your house.  You have $500 to decorate it.  What is the largest size carpet that you can buy? Choices:  C: 5m x 5m D: 8m x 8m E: 7m x 7m F: 16m x 16m <n><n>### Response to A:<n>Choices: F<n><n>- This cannot be calculated. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What happens to cats every day? Choices:  A: open doors B: drink water C: need food D: annoy E: play<n><n>### Response:		 What happens to the dog?<n><n>### Input Two cats walk towards John at the door.  One cat can jump 1 meter, the other can jump 4 meters.  Can they open the door: Choices:  A. Yes B. No<n><n>### Response<n>How high can a cat jump?<n><n>## Solution<n>A common task that appears in coding interviews is to understand two simple properties of a number and how addition or subtraction of two simple properties or simple functions might effect those properties.<n><n>Consider the following:<n>| n1 | n2 | Operation |<n>| -: | -: | -:     |<n>|  0 |  9  | sub      | 10  |<n>|  9  |  0  | sub      | -9  |<n>|  0  |  9  | add      |  0  |<n>| -9  |  0   | add      | -8  |<n><n>To understand the above operations on 9 and 0, we ask, when the result of addition/subtraction is n and n is divisible by 3, what is the sum of each number in the addition/subtraction?<n>For add, (0+9) = 1 and for sub, (-9-0) = -9<n><n>Without knowing it, this question may have been asked on an algorithm interview before. Consider this algorithm:<n><n>def sumN_N(N,n):<n>    if n%N == 0:<n>        return sumN_N(n/2, N)<n>    else:<n>        return n<n><n>To find the sum of a number, N, we can check if n is divisible by N. If N is a multiple of N, then the number is divisible by N and we can stop the loop.<n><n>## References<n>This question is commonly asked in a few of the following topics on Hackerrank:<n> 1. [Dynamic Programming](https://www.hackerrank.com/challenges/dynamic-programming/problem),<n> 2. [Functions](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dj5HpZ4YL9k)<n>

Choices:  A: movies B: opera C: theater D: lecture hall E: hockey game<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you guessed "theater" then you are correct.<n><n><n>### Input:[{"id": "n403d1","product_sku":"54525"}, {"id": "n427e6","product_sku":"18875"}]<n>[{"id": "n365f4","price_in_cents":102418}, {"id": "n253b7","price_in_cent":10243}]<n><n>### Response<n><n>1) <n>[{"line": {"price_in_centes":102423},"product_sku":"15426"},{"line": {"price": 587871},"product_sku": "40099"}]<n><n>2)<n>[{"line":  {"price_in_cetnts":102447},"product_sku":{"id": "n498n7","price_in4_cwnts":101234}},"product_sku":{"id" "":"n7848e","price_in_cmnts":105247}]<n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:John lives in Texas. If he takes the highway South and doesn't stop, where will he end up next? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: developed land C: united states D: desert E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n>**C**. United States<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions:Farmers harvest 2 tons of rice and 2 tons of beans every month.  One metric ton of rice costs $120 and one metric ton of beans costs $100 per ton.  A farmer gets paid with a percentage of the total profit from the crop he raises.  What percent of the total profit will he earn if the 2 tons of rice cost $1000 total?<n><n>---<n><n># 1 : What percent of the total sale value would he earn if the beans cost him a total of $2000?<n><n>% = ([$100/total] * [100/2000])*100 = $(50/200) * (5/100) = 1.25%<n><n># 2 : What percentage would she earn if beans cost her $3500?<n><n><n><n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What happens to the next appointment when a grooming takes longer than expected? Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input A and B:<n>A: James visits his dog every Tuesday and Thursday for a 30 minute grooming. He always stays for 30 minutes after grooming for feeding.<n><n>B A: The grooming does not take less than 1 hour.  If the grooming takes longer than 1 hour, he will get annoyed. He will not cancel the appointment if it runs over by 30 minutes or less.<n><n>### Response B and C<n><n>B A: He always cancels appointments when the grooming takes more than 1 hour. If the grooming takes less than 1 hour, there is no reaction or cancellation.<n><n>B B: He will get angry if the appointments run longer than 20% of the total time. He will cancel the appointment if it takes over 1.2 hours.<n><n>B C: He doesn’t mind when appointments run long. He doesn’t even notice them.  If the groomer canceels more than 25% of the scheduled appointments, James will look for another groomer.<n><n>### Input D and E<n><n>D A: James is happy if the grooming takes over 1 hour but less than 2 hours.  If it takes longer than 2 hours and is less than 3 hours, he gets annoyed.  If over 3 hours and less than 4 hours, James cancels the appointments.<n><n>E A: He will never leave if the grooming takes longer.  James will leave if the appointments take over 1.5 hours.<n><n>

Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What does moving cars entail? Choices:  A: driving B: road C: getting tired D: accidents E: ticket<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  Please write a Python script that answers the above question. Here is what your script should do:<n><n>1. Use a dictionary. To do this, set the data key "moving_cars" to a dictionary and then create 6 key-value pairs underneath for the choices with values for each choice.<n>2. Looping over all choices for your dictionary, prompt the user for input.<n>3. For the choice A, use the driving_time key from input, the keys distance and time from data, and the value of time 40 from data to calculate the total miles driven in one hour.<n>4. When a choice B, use the data key "road" with the value of "driving speed" to calculate the distance traveled in one hour for the same condition.<n>5. When a choice C, prompt the user for the number of hours in which they were driving, and then call the get_expenses method from the dictionary.<n>6. When a choice D, prompt the user to choose an option to select an accident. Then prompt the user to choose a choice to select a ticket, followed by selecting the type of ticket.<n>7. When a choice E, use the price per gallon value from the dictionary key "gas_price" to print out the total amount owed for gas, along with the miles driven.<n>8. When a choice F, add gas and parking costs to the value for each key in the dictionary for moving_cars. Then, call the to_python method, and print out the dictionary's list() as well as their values.<n><n>### Output<n><n>Examine the below output to determine the task response.<n><n>```<n>Please tell me how much you want to spend: 500<n>Which would you like to rent: A: Moving Truck B: SUV<n>Please tell me how far your moving distance is: 50 miles<n>Please tell me how long your moving time is: 15 hours<n><n>Please tell me if you have more than 3 boxes: <n><n>Would you like  to pay a flat rate? A: Yes B: No<n>A: Moving Truck<n>A: 5 miles per hour<n>B: SUV<n>B: 30 miles per hour<n><n>A: Yes<n>A: 24<n>A: 50 miles per hour

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:If you see blinking lights in the air at night, what are you usually looking at? Choices:  A: carnival B: plane C: concert D: turned at night E: a penguin's bum<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>``` ruby<n>def carnival<n>  puts "A - Carnival"<n>end<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>```<n>A<n>```<n><n>## 37.<n><n>### Problem 37:<n>Write an algorithm that can sum the digits of an integer. For example, "123" should return "1+2+3=6" instead of "1+1+1=3".<n><n>### Test:<n>Input: 9<n>Output: 9 should only output 9.<n>```ruby<n>def sum_digits(digits)<n>  result = 0<n>  (digits.to_i).split('').each do |digit|<n>    result += digit.to_i<n>  end<n>  result<n>end<n><n>puts(sum_digits(9))<n>```<n><n>##  38.<n><n>### Tutorial 38:<n>- [ ] 1. Create "hello world" and get familiarized with `main function`<n>- [ ] 2. Understand ruby basics with an application<n><n>### Output Expected:<n>```<n>A - Carnival<n>```<n><n>## Task<n>Write an output that corresponds to the input. Answer the question.<n><n>## Time requirement<n>5 min <n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:There weren't enough chairs for everyone.  What might have to be delayed? Choices:  A: bookstore B: building C: meeting D: office E: coffeehouse<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Inside a bookstore is a line of people waiting to get in. There are only 3 chairs for everyone. If the line doesn't move fast enough then it would make sense to delay one of the following things: A: The meeting in the building, B: The bookstore employee's next restroom break, C: The office employee's lunch break, or D: The library employee's next meeting.<n><n>### Output:<n>### Explanation<n><n>The correct answer is A: The meeting. You can either have 3 chairs for a meeting of 5 people and the meeting starts whenever it starts, or 2 chairs and one person has to sit at their desk while holding in their pee or they can hold it until after the next restroom break. Or for three meetings (and the 4th person is holding someone else's chair to not be pushed out of the line) you could just call the 4th meeting for tomorrow and not let anyone in until they've had their meeting.<n>

Create methods to find a book by an id<n><n>In this task, you need to create two methods to find a book in a collection.<n><n>### Task 2:<n>#### Instruction:<n>Write a method that takes a book ID as a parameter and outputs the book. The method should not include the book.<n><n>In this task we only need to handle the one kind of error.<n><n>* An exception error is expected when the ID is not used.<n><n>```ruby <n>exception Error.new("Book does not exist")<n>```<n><n>```ruby<n>def find_with_given_id<n>  book = Books_data.find {|book| book.id == @book_id}<n>  if book.nil?<n>    raise BookDoesNotExist<n>  end<n>rescue BookDoesNotExist => e<n>  puts "#{e.message}" # print out the error message<n>  end<n>  book<n>end<n>```<n>```<n><n>### Show your work<n><n>### [Show your work for task #1 here]<n><n>### [Task #2 Show your work here]<n><n># Task 3. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:If you harm property after starting a fire where are you likely to end up? Choices:  A: damage B: going to jail C: going to school D: burns E: destruction<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you harm property after setting a fire you likely to end up in jail.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Because in my opinion, the only consequence of starting a fire is going to jail. I might have missed a choice or not.<n><n>    /*<n>    To understand, you must be able to explain your reasoning. If you cannot, your submission will be rejected.<n>    Your explanation should be at least 15 words per multiple choice question to be accepted<n>    The goal of the task is to encourage the submission of correct answers<n>    Including comments about your submissions will allow the Community to better understand your work<n>    */<n>        <n>    #!/bin/python3<n>    import math<n>    # Complete the multiple_choice function below.<n>    def multiple_choice(choice, totalCost, choice2, totalCost2, choice3, totalCost3, choice4, totalCost4):<n>        <n>    ### Please provide only ONE COMMENT for each question below<n>    <n>    # 1<n>    print(choice1) print(choice2) print(choice3)  print(choice4)<n>    print(choice5)<n>    if any(math.isnan(totalCost) for totalCost in (totalCost1, totalCost2, totalCost3, totalCost4)):<n>        if choice1 == choice5 and choice3 == choice5 and choice5 == choice5: print("Ans : Option A")<n>        elif choice1 == choice5: print (<n>        "No answer"<n>        ) or<n>        choice2 == choice5<n>        or<n>        choice3 == choice5<n>        elif choice1: print("Ans: Option B  ", end = '')<n>        elif choice2 == choice5:  print("Ans:Option B ", end = '')<n>        elif choice3 == choice5: <n>        print("Ans: B ", end = '') if (choice4 == choice5 or choice5 == choice4): print("Ans:C ", end = '')<n>        <n>    <n>    #2.<n><n>    if choice1 == choice2 == choice3 == choice4:<n>        print(choice3, choice2, choice1, choice4, choice5, )

How often should you eating fast food in order to be more likely to survive? <n>Answer: 0.764692058823531<n><n>### Input.<n>### Response<n>The heart attack, fish and chips and chances of survival. So by eating fish and chips everyday that will reduce the risk of heart attack by 80 % which is 0.8. If I eat fish and chips every day, then my chances of surviving increases which is 1.8. So the answer is 1.8<n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What is a child likely to do while going to play? Choices:  A: laugh B: sit C: happiness D: being entertained E: walk slowly<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n><n>child=raw_input('what kind of activity is the child going to do')<n>if child=='A':<n>    print "laugh"<n>elif child=='B':<n>    print "sit"<n>elif child== 'C':<n>    print "happiness"<n>elif child== "D":<n>    print "being entertained"<n>elif child=="E":<n>    print "walk"<n>else:<n>    print "wrong answer"<n>    <n>```<n>

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:where do you store wine? Choices:  A: attic B: basement C: art show D: church E: bar<n><n>### Response:		I keep my wine in the attic as it is better sheltered from light. Also, basement is not accessible throughout the year.<n><n>*I do not keep wine in the cellar as it's best for beer.*<n><n>### Output:<n><n>The final price should be $9<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>Input:How much do you tip a restaurant? Choices: 55% to the waitress, 22%, 17% or 80% to the cook, 0%<n><n>### Response<n><n>In all cases the tips are always higher than $5. If the cook is the waitress, he gets 55%. If no one waits for you, 22% is the default recommendation. If a tip has not been given, 80% is given for the cook.<n><n>### Output<n><n>* If the tip is for a waitress, he will always get 55% in total.<n>* If the tip does not refer to a waitress, the 22% for the waiter will apply.<n>* Finally, the tip must always be higher than $5.

The first plant is located in London and the second plant is in Chicago.  The company is going to upgrade and re-open plant two to start manufacturing.  The company expects the cost of running the plant to not change and the cost of running the first plant is expected to remain constant.  Which of the following statements about plant costs is true?<n><n>*  A.  It is more expensive to manufacture with plant 2<n>*  B.  Both plants cost the same to run and the company would be better off closing plant one if it could close only one of the plants.<n>*  C.  More efficient plant will allow the company to reduce the overall cost of product.<n>*  D.  In the long run the overall cost of products will be higher because it is cheaper to make.<n><n>### Answer: If a is true, choics is C. If B is true, choies is D. If A is true, chouices is B. Choices:  A: city centre B: lottery ticket C: maps D: street E: busy city<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```<n>input:	What could you find at the bus station that can help me answer the question?<n>answer:	Let's take a look at what you could find in a bus station!<n>		A: Let's start with the city center!<n>`			Bus stations are located in busy city centers so it's likely you'll find some information in the city center that can help answer your question, like maps!<n>			One way to find maps in the city center is...<n>		B: A lottery ticket can solve a problem I'm having!<n>		You might not have thought you were at a place to find a lottery ticket, but maybe you were!<n>			Lotteries draw numbers from all over the world, so this would be a great place to buy a lottery ticket.<n>		C: Let's look at maps!<n>		Maps are a great resource to...<n>		D: Maps come in handy!<n>			Maps provide directions to places you'd like to go by giving a detailed layout of the area.<n>			That's why if there is a bus station in town, it's highly likely that a map is available at the bus station!<n>	E: Let's look in each of the letters and see what's best!<n>```

The choice of which to go by may also depend on the category.  For example, Sci-fi is a subgenre of thriller for some audiences. Choices:  A: company B: airport C: wall D: computer network E: love<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n># input: [a b c d e]<n>def answer(a,b,c,d,e):<n>  if (e == 'A' or e == 'C'):<n>    return [10,10]<n>  else:<n>    return [a - b,a - c]<n>answer(x)<n>  if a < b and (c > b or d > b or e > b) :<n>    return len(a) > x - a<n>```<n>input: Adam bought 3 kg of nuts and 1 kg of dried fruits in a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:If a student was about to graduate, they would no longer be attending what? Choices:  A: library B: parties C: kindergarten class D: bar E: school<n><n>### Response:		A: library.<n><n>### Challenge:1<n><n>Use recursion to create a method that takes in two parameter and returns the largest of the parameters.<n><n>**Examples**<n>For example, if your parameters are 5 and 6 then you return 6.<n>**Answer:**<n><n><n>**Test 1**<n>Enter 4, 6<n><n>**Test 2**<n>Enter 15, 11<n><n>### Solution:<n>Solution:<n> <n>```python<n>  def recursionLarger(a, b):<n>  if (a > b):<n>      return a<n>  else:<n>      return b<n> ```<n><n>### Challenge :2<n>Solving a challenge problem is a skill on it's own.<n>**Exercise:** Think in terms of pseudo code and draw your diagrams. Then, try the solution in python.<n><n><n>1. I want help with this challenge from my python group<n>https://www.meetup.com/Python-Programming/cities/us/wa/seattle-2/<n>

Write a function doubleAndSum(arr) that accepts and returns nothing. It must convert every number in the array to an integer and double it. 2. Then, write a function sumOfPrecursors(num, arr). How many hours did the flight take?<n>  (3) (4) (2) (6)<n>Answer: 2<n>```<n>In this task I have to write the response to how much time did the plane take?<n><n>##### Response:In this task i have to take the same

Choices:  A: place of work B: office C: friend's house D: workplace E: deep thought<n><n>### Response:		 Let us call human B and ask B if A wants to go home. If it is true human A goes home. If it is not true B has already decided.<n><n><n>### Input :  Adam went with his friend, Anna, and their children, Sam and Julia, to go on a hike after school.   The hike was 5 miles long and took them 2 hours to do. It took Sam, the 10-year old, 2 ½ hours to complete the hike and he felt exhausted.  Julia the 8-year old, felt excited as she completed the hike in less than 2 hours and stayed with her family.    What was the elapsed time of the hike for Anna and their children together?<n><n>### Response  :  Let us call the elapsed time as a function E. The elapsed time E(x) for Julia was T(x) and for Sam it was (9-x T(x)) because of the equation f(x)=(9-x)g(x) and g(x)=-13+3x=T(x)

Create a temporary variable (i and temp) for each character in the input<n>4.   Create a new variable (str) to store the reversed string and initialize it as empty<n>5.   For each character in the input in reverse order (starting from the last character of the input)<n>   1.   If the current character is a letter<n>       1.   Add the current character to the beginning of temp<n>       2.   Reverse the linked list by using pop()<n>       3.   Change the current character to the last character, but don't assign temp.current back yet<n>       4.   Add the current reversed linked list into the new_reversed_list using push()<n>5.   Add the last character of temp into str and assign temp.current = empty<n>6. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What would you do if you want to be able to earn money? Choices:  A: apply for job B: stand in line C: take care of proposals D: pass course E: play the lottery<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: B<n>Input: B -> B -> A -> B<n>Input: B<n><n>### Input&Reason: You’re a salesperson who needs to go over all your products. You have two stores, one in a city by the lake and another in the city center. Since you have to take a 60 minute train ride across the lake to get to the city center, you’d prefer to choose your first store to be the one closer to your home. You decide to take the train from your city to the city center at 7 am, and you plan to go over all the products by 10 am so you can go to a nearby grocery store and get lunch before heading back home. Since you need to get back at 3 pm before going home, you know that the trains from the city center to your city depart at 2 pm. What’s the earliest that you should start working at the city in the lake to make sure you don’t miss a train back home?

Choices:  A: mountains countryside B: ground C: bridge D: mountain range E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer D.<n><n>### Explanation: Mountains are higher than ground. Bridges are lower than ground. So, a rock would fall short if it is thrown from either of these. To make a splash in the river, then the only choice is the surface of earth.<n><n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>#### This is a task instruction that describes a task that must be completed with three subtasks. The length of the rectangle<n><n>####<n><n>8. Subtask 3: Add in variable(s) 7 and 2 and multiply<n><n>####<n><n>9. Length of the rectangle<n><n>10. Width of rectangle<n><n>11. Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n><n>### Response:		The answer choice, C, is correct.<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>Alice and Bob went to buy a TV.  Alice bought a TV and a coffee table.  It cost her $627 and Bob bought a phone case that cost $46.  How much did Alice spend after taxes?<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>The answer choice is correct.<n><n>The question asks for the amount after tax. The tax applied is the same to all the items bought. Therefore, it is calculated as sum of all prices of items bought * taxrate. Alice price after tax $627 (10 * 627) and Bobs after tax is 46*(10/100) = $4.6<n><n>### Input<br><n>`What did Bill earn last week?`<br><n>`$1420`<br><br><n>`What do I have to pay him then?`<n><n>### Process<n><n>First determine how much Bill got from last week. Then determine what the answer from the question is.<n><n>```Python<n>1500 + 700 + 1300 + 200<n>#350<n>```<n><n>## Expected outputs<n>A string variable of 5 symbols which is the price of his total sale(product and freight for sale)<n>Then, the answer option which is the answer given by the user.<n><n>## Outputs<n>A string variable of input message<n>And a string variable of input question<n><n>## Expected inputs<n>A function is implemented to calculate the sale of the products.<n>```python<n>#a = product a<n>#product b<n>#f = total freight<n>#total price = a * price a * f + b * price b * f<n>```<n><n>```python<n>a = PriceOfProduct(50,12,2)<n>b = PriceOfProduct(1,10,3)<n><n>product_sale_price = a * 50 + b * 1<n>sale_price = product_sale_price * 2<n>total_sale = product_sale price + freight_fee<n>total_sale_price_without_tax = total_sale<n>```<n><n>Then, an user input.<n>```python<n>input("What did Bill earn and

Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The person is laying on the beach, why would he do that? Each comment must be at least 100 characters in length and include a valid sentence. <n><n>### Response 1:<n>A comment can be used to provide a brief description of the program to someone who works on your project. It is also useful to indicate where certain codes were located. Another benefit of comments in a program is to keep information about the code that might be needed in the future. Finally, a good comment should be informative and detailed to someone who will need to understand what your program does.<n><n>### Benefits:<n>A comment can help to explain an error.  It can also provide a description of your project.  Another benefit of a comment is to improve the flow of a program. Finally, comments can be helpful to improve the legibility of a program.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>A: B: C: D: E: 300<n><n>### Benifits of Comments:<n>### Benifets of Comments<n>### Benifet<n><n><n><n># Data Structure Design<n>## Data Structures<n>A **data structure** in computer science is an organization of data ______ a way to solve a problem. It can give an efficient way to store and organize data.<n>A structure could be an array, dictionary, list, set or hash table. It should be efficient, scalable and should keep in mind the purpose of the project.<n><n>There should always be a balance between what data structure is best for the situation and how much the code does based on the data structure.<n><n>Arrays store data in a single line of memory<n><n>Lists sort in memory then store elements<n><n>Sets provide an efficient way to search for specific elements.<n><n>Hash Maps/Tables are like linked lists but they can have several data structures.<n><n>## Linked Lists<n>A data structure is a ________ data structure that stores data at multiple physical locations. <n>It does not have the same features in memory as arrays. <n>To work with a linked list, you

'<n>   2. "<n>   3. #$%<n>* What comes fourteenth?<n>   1.\<n>   2. %/<n>   3.!*<n>* What comes fifteenth?<n>   1.$<n>   2%#<n>   3&%<n>* What comes sixteenth?<n>   1."/<n>   2. $/<n>   3. &$<n>* What comes seventeenth?<n>   1."<n>   2.$/<n>   3. *$<n>* What comes eighteenth?<n>   1*<n>   2&/<n>   3&#<n>* What comes nineteenth?<n>   1&/&<n>   2.*<n>   3.*/$<n>* What comes twentieth?<n>   1.*/$&<n>   2. #&<n>   3.*$<n>* What comes twenty first?<n>   1.*&<n>   2.*!<n>   3. *!<n>* What comes twentyth second?<n>   1.*!/#<n>   2.*!/#/<n>   3.*

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where can you store you tent and keep it on your person? Choices:  A: sleep in while camping B: camp ground C: woods D: bag E: backpack<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n><n># This line will tell the program which response and answer you chose<n>answer = "c"<n><n>if answer == "c":<n>    location = "B"<n>else:<n>    location = "A"<n><n>if answer in ("a", "b"):<n><n>        print("Here is our tent stored up on our person:")<n>else:<n><n>    print("Here is how we should keep our tent stored up on someone person:")<n><n>if answer == location:<n>    print("You passed!")<n>else:<n>    print("Oh well! Try again next time")<n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n># A:  Your family is looking at camping this summer.  Where is the best place to try tent camping, with options:<n><n>A:  in your backyard, at a park, or at a campground. Your family is going to try it out a local park for now and they want to know where they should invest more money to do so. Choices:<n><n>A: in your backyard, park, or campground<n>B: park or campground<n>C: backyard or park<n>D: campground or park<n>E: Park or campground<n><n>### Response<n><n>```<n># This line will use our input value to tell the program which question we're being asked, and which answer we should be returning.<n>value = "A"<n>answer = value<n>if answer == 'a':<n>    print("Hello there and welcome to our park area")<n>else:<n>  print("We have a few options for setting up tents. Let's start with A: campground")<n>if answer == 'b':<n>  print("This is the best area I can think of with your available options. ")<n>elif answer == 'c':<n>    print("Our backyard only takes on average a ton of light but not rain.  This will make it hard to feel like you're getting your money's worth from here  ")<n>elif answer =='d':<n>    print("We have a ton of different campgrounds that you can set up your tent")<n>elif answer =='e':<n>    print('Well, we have a ton of different options!  Which one do you want to do this year?')<n>```<n><n>## Conclusion:<n>This is the final step. You must write this conclusion in

Choices:  A: hatred B: surprised C: compliments D: dedication E: solutions<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>#### Input: Write a method that has a one-to-one correspondence between one-line messages and their length in words.<n><n>#### Demonstration: Write a method that will take a String (that's the content of your message) and return an integer representing its length measured in words.<n>#### Input: "Ten, -, -, - is a great number."<n>Response: 12<n><n>#### Response:<n>Your solution should return the number of words in a given sentence.<n><n>#### Solution:<n><n>#### Lint Errors:<n><n><details><summary>Show Solution</summary><x-alert-message>I forgot to close the method</x-alert-message></details><n>```kotlin<n>// solution<n>fun lengthOfWordsMethod(message: String) {<n>  var counter = message.length<n><n>  message.split(" ").forEach {<n>      if (message!= null){<n>          return true<n>          counter -= 1<n><n>         return<n>      }<n>  }<n><n><n>  if (message.isNotEmpty()) {<n>     return counter<n>  }<n>}<n>```<n><n><details><x-alert-warning>In addition</x-alert-warning></details><n>```<n>fun main(args: Array<String>) {<n>  if(true){<n>    message = "Ten, -1, -2, -3, is a great."<n>  }<n>} // or I can define a method in the main method<n><n>message.split(" ").sorted().forEach {<n>   if (message!= null) {<n>    // solution<n>}<n><n>}<n>```<n>

Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where do most people keep their curling iron stored? Choices:  A: bathroom B: walkway C: use D: hair salon E: drawer<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are many places to store a curling iron. One could keep it in the bathroom, but that is very much a convenience.<n>For the curling iron to really function properly it needs to be stored where all the hair is being curled.<n>If it is in the drawer it prevents a constant amount of hair from falling into the iron.<n>This prevents the iron from burning anything it doesn’t have in it.<n>In the hair salon keeps the curling iron from getting burned by hair.<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answers with multiple choice questions are provided below.<n>	- A. Housing costs are very expensive in Toronto, so it is hard to find an apartment at a reasonable price.<n>	- B. The house isn’t finished yet, so the value is very low. <n><n>### Instrument Name:Curling Iron<n>### Input:How do curling irons work?<n>### Instruction Text:<n>The curling iron works when the small rod inside the curling iron heats up and sticks to your hair.<n>The clamp on the curling iron will lock in the hair so you can curl the hair around the iron.<n>Once the hair is around the iron, it is turned to release the clamping mechanism.<n>The hair is left twisted and you are left with a curl.<n><n>### Direction:You can use either short answers or a paragraph to complete this.<n>How do curling irresons work?<n>Curling irons are devices that heat metal rods used to get hairstyles such as curls and waves.<n>How do you use a curling iron?<n>The metal rods on curling irons become heated hot through the use of electricity.<n>The rod has a clamp that will lock your hair into the heat.<n>When the rod is twisted around a hair strand it curls it.<n>

Fill in the blanks.<n><n>### Method: <n>* Define the name of the variable.<n>* Define in the first set of brackets the value of the first number, if any.<n>* Define an empty array in the second set of brackets.<n>* List in the third set of brackets one by one any two numbers.<n>* List the last one in ascending order and assign the value of the empty array.<n><n>### Sample: Input: Define the name of the constant variable:  A. m B. s C. km<n><n>* Define in the second set of parentheses the value of the constant m<n>* Define the first set of parentheses and the value 4<n>* Define second set of parentheses 2 and 6<n>* Assign 42, which is the third set of parentheses to y<n><n>### Input<n><n>m[0] = 1, m[1] = 5<n><n>### Output<n><n>The output should be 52<n>### Demonestration<n><n>**Note:**<n><n>The numbers in the first set of parentheses come second<n>### Instruciton<n><n>### Method<n><n>* First set of brackets has a random number.<n>* Second set of brackets is a random variable called the index <n><n>### Sample<n><n><ul><li>Variable A<n><li>Variable B<n><li>Function A<n><li>Function B<n><li>Operation (+)<n><li>Constant 1<n><li>Constat 32.<n><li><n><li>Variable C<n><li>Variable D<n><li>Const 1<n><li>{
